The columns ID, RA, Dec. and <em>z</em> represent the identification number, the right ascension, the declination and the redshift of each entry. The column CONFID represents the confidence level of the detection, from 3 for very secure down to 1 for less secure identifications according to our grading policy, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.4</a>. TYPE represents the classification of the object based on the system used for the MUSE-UDF analysis (Bacon et\u00a0al.\u2009in preparation): TYPE=0 are stars, TYPE=2 are [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters, TYPE=3 are absorption line galaxies, TYPE=4 are C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii]</span> emitters and TYPE=6 are Lyman-\u03b1 emitters (the other MUSE-UDF TYPE do not match any entries of this catalogue). The MUL column shows the multiple image ID if it is reported in our strong-lensing analysis. Columns named FXXXW and FXXXW_ERR present the photometry and its error in the seven <em>HST</em> filters used in this study. MU and MU_ERR represent the magnification ratio and its error computed from our lensing mass model. Objects MXX are only detected in the MUSE cube as they do not match any entry from our photometric catalogue.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>FID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>_ERR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>...<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>_ERR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>_ERR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[deg]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[deg]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>M39\u00a0</td><td>3.5889097\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.3821391\u00a0</td><td>6.6439\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>2.221\u00a0</td><td>0.061\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2115\u00a0</td><td>3.5938048\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4154482\u00a0</td><td>6.5876\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>&gt;29.44\u00a0</td><td>99.0\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>26.70\u00a0</td><td>0.0383\u00a0</td><td>3.575\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>M38\u00a0</td><td>3.5801476\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4079034\u00a0</td><td>6.5565\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>2.958\u00a0</td><td>0.084\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>M37\u00a0</td><td>3.5830603\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4118859\u00a0</td><td>6.5195\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>2.868\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10609\u00a0</td><td>3.598419\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.3872993\u00a0</td><td>6.3755\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>&gt;30.39\u00a0</td><td>99.0\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>30.00\u00a0</td><td>0.3039\u00a0</td><td>1.768\u00a0</td><td>0.051\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5353\u00a0</td><td>3.6010732\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4039891\u00a0</td><td>6.3271\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>&gt;29.57\u00a0</td><td>99.0\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>28.04\u00a0</td><td>0.0938\u00a0</td><td>3.821\u00a0</td><td>0.133\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>CON-<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>TYPE<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n .\u00a0</span></th><th>F435W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>...<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F160W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F160W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>MU<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>MU<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>FID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>_ERR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>...<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>_ERR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>_ERR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[deg]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[deg]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[mag]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>M39\u00a0</td><td>3.5889097\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.3821391\u00a0</td><td>6.6439\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>2.221\u00a0</td><td>0.061\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2115\u00a0</td><td>3.5938048\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4154482\u00a0</td><td>6.5876\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>&gt;29.44\u00a0</td><td>99.0\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>26.70\u00a0</td><td>0.0383\u00a0</td><td>3.575\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>M38\u00a0</td><td>3.5801476\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4079034\u00a0</td><td>6.5565\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>2.958\u00a0</td><td>0.084\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>M37\u00a0</td><td>3.5830603\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4118859\u00a0</td><td>6.5195\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>2.868\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10609\u00a0</td><td>3.598419\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.3872993\u00a0</td><td>6.3755\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>&gt;30.39\u00a0</td><td>99.0\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>30.00\u00a0</td><td>0.3039\u00a0</td><td>1.768\u00a0</td><td>0.051\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5353\u00a0</td><td>3.6010732\u00a0</td><td>\u221230.4039891\u00a0</td><td>6.3271\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>\u201d\u201d\u00a0</td><td>&gt;29.57\u00a0</td><td>99.0\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>28.04\u00a0</td><td>0.0938\u00a0</td><td>3.821\u00a0</td><td>0.133\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>...\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98964821\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compared the MUSE redshift catalogue presented here to the NED data base, checking in particular the redshifts presented by the GLASS team (Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). In Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec9\"></span><a href=\"#sec9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a>, we list corrections made to redshifts published in the literature based on the MUSE data.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964823 id=\"98964823\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 STRONG-LENSING ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we provide a brief summary of the gravitational lensing analysis technique used in this work. We refer the reader to Kneib et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), Verdugo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) for more details.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964825 id=\"98964825\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Methodology</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Although many different analysis methods exist throughout the literature, they can generally be classified into two broad categories. The first category, known as parametric methods, use analytic profiles for mass potentials and rely on a range of parameters to describe the entire cluster mass distribution. The second category, referred to as non-parametric methods, make no strong assumption on the shape of the mass profile. Instead, the mass is derived from an evolving pixel-grid minimization. In this study, we take a parametric approach, using <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) to model the cluster mass distribution as a series of dual pseudo-isothermal ellipsoids (dPIE, El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), which are optimized through a Monte Carlo Markov Chain minimization.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To model the cluster mass distribution, dark matter (hereafter DM) dPIE clumps are combined to map the DM at the cluster scale. Galaxy-scale DM potentials are used to describe galaxy-scale substructure. Considering the number of galaxies in the cluster, including several hundred in the core alone, it is not feasible to optimize the parameters of every potential, as the large parameter space will lead to an unconstrained minimization. Moreover, individual galaxies contribute only a small fraction to the total mass budget of the cluster, so their effects on lensing are minimal at most. To reduce the overall parameter space, we scale the parameters of each galaxy to a reference value, using a constant mass\u2013luminosity scaling relation given by the following equations: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\sigma _0&amp;=&amp;\\sigma _{0}^{*}\\left(\\frac{L}{L^{*}}\\right)^{1/4},\\nonumber\\\\\r\n r_{\\rm core}&amp;=&amp; r_{\\rm core}^{*}\\left(\\frac{L}{L^{*}}\\right)^{1/2},\\nonumber\\\\\r\n r_{\\rm cut}&amp;=&amp;r_{\\rm cut}^{*}\\left(\\frac{L}{L^{*}}\\right)^{1/2}\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{0}^{*}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^{*}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^{*}$|</span> are the parameters of an <em>L</em>* galaxy. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^{*}$|</span> is fixed at 0.15\u00a0kpc as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^{*}$|</span> is expected to be small at galaxy scales and also degenerate with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{0}^{*}$|\u2060</span>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some galaxies in the FoV are not expected to follow this relation, based on their unique properties or formation histories. As a result, we remove these objects from the scaling relation to avoid biasing the results. One prominent example is the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) which will have a significantly different mass-to-light ratio and size, since it is the centre point of the merging process. As advised by Newman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>), the two BCGs of A2744 are modelled separately. In addition, bright (therefore massive) galaxies behind the cluster can also contribute to the lensing effect near the core, so we include them in the galaxy sample, but model them separately from the scaling relation. In order to normalize the effects of these galaxies on the model, we rescale their total masses based on their line-of-sight (LOS) distance from the cluster. These \u2018projected-mass\u2019 galaxy potentials are then optimized.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the complexity of the cluster, the strong-lensing models are optimized iteratively, starting with the most obvious strong-lensing constraints (as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3.2</a>). After the initial run concludes, parameters are then adjusted and the set of constraints can be reconsidered. Once these changes are made, another minimization is started and the model is revised according to the new results. This offers the possibility of testing different hypotheses, such as adding DM clumps or including an external shear field. Throughout this process, multiple image constraints can be paired differently and new counter-image positions can be identified by their proximity to the model predictions. Ending this iterative process is not obvious and an arbitrary level of satisfaction is needed to stop. In this work, the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> value and rms statistics measured with respect to the observed positions of multiply imaged galaxies are used to rank different models and priors.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964830 id=\"98964830\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Selection of cluster members</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To construct a catalogue of cluster members, we start with the colour\u2013colour selection from Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>): all galaxies that fall within 3\u03c3 of a linear model of the cluster red sequence in both the (<em>m</em><sub>F606W</sub>\u2013<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub> and the (<em>m</em><sub>F435W</sub>\u2013<em>m</em><sub>F606W</sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams. However, we limit ourselves to only those galaxies contained within the WFC3 FoV. This is because the WFC3 field approximately matches the MUSE FoV, allowing us to focus on modelling the cluster core (see Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, and reference therein). As mentioned in the previous section, cluster members included in the mass model are scaled through a mass-to-light relation. In order to better fit the scaling relation to the selected galaxies, we take magnitudes from the ASTRODEEP photometric catalogue (see Merlin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a> and Castellano et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a> for a complete view of the catalogue making process). When available, we use the ASTRODEEP magnitudes for our objects, since they assume a S\u00e9rsic model fit of galaxy photometry. Compared to our photometric catalogue, a major difference can be seen in bright objects. This is due to the broad limit between galaxy wings and ICL, which we remove with our median filtering. In cases where an F814W magnitude is not available from ASTRODEEP, we substitute it with the photometry of the catalogue detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Because faint cluster galaxies far from lensed arcs only have a small lensing effect, only galaxies brighter than 0.01 <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> are included in the final galaxy selection (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub> &lt;24.44; M\u22481.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup>\u2009M\u2299, Natarajan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The global effect of missing cluster members will be degenerate with the total mass in the large-scale DM clumps.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, galaxies that match the initial colour selection but have confirmed redshifts outside of the cluster range [0.29\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.33] (see Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) are removed from the cluster member catalogue (8), while non-colour-matched galaxies with a confirmed cluster redshift are included (21). After all of this, we are left with 246 cluster galaxies out of which a large fraction (156) have spectroscopic redshifts. As described in Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1</a>, this large sample of cluster members provide vital information about the cluster dynamics.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964833 id=\"98964833\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Strong-lensing constraints</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This section describes our methodology of categorizing multiply imaged systems and details the reviewing of all known multiple systems used and reported in the strong-lensing analyses of A2744. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> summarizes the number of systems, images and spectroscopic redshifts from each study.</p>                        <a id=\"98964835\" scrollto-destination=\"98964835\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Number of images and systems reported in the strong-lensing analyses of A2744 to date. <em>N</em><sub>sys,z</sub> gives the number of systems having at least one image confirmed with a spectroscopic redshift and used in the model, <em>N</em><sub>im,z</sub> the number of images confirmed with a redshift in these systems, compared to the total number of systems (<em>N</em><sub>sys</sub>) and images (<em>N</em><sub>im</sub>) presented. The bold value highlight the value of this study.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Study<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>sys,z</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>im,z</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>sys</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>im</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>pre-HFF\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2003Merten et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and Johnson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) constructed a catalogue of 55 multiple systems, including three secure spectroscopic redshifts for systems 3, 4 and 6 (Johnson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Later work by Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), Lam et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), Ishigaki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and Kawamata et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) proposed \u223c185 additional images from the analysis of the HFF data. This includes spectroscopic redshifts of seven lensed sources found by the GLASS team (Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) measured for images 1.3, 2.1, 3.1 and 3.2, 4.3 and 4.5, 6.1, 6.2 and 6.3, 18.3, 22.1. The spectroscopic measurement for system 55 are associated with the same sources as system 1 (see Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a> for details). The existing numbers of multiple imaged systems (<em>N</em><sub>sys</sub>) and the total number of source images in these (<em>N</em><sub>im</sub>) as well as the fraction of spectroscopically confirmed redshifts are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=98964837 id=\"98964837\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-1>4.3.1 Incorporating MUSE spectroscopic constraints</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use all confidence levels 2 and 3 MUSE redshifts to check the multiplicity and the reliability of each multiple system. While Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) report a detection of H\u03b1 line at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.8630 for image 1.3 with good confidence (Quality 3), the analysis of the stacked MUSE spectrum of system 1 leads to a secure redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.688 based on multiple features (see in the Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec9\"></span><a href=\"#sec9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a> for details). As in their study, we also consider systems 55 and 1 belong to the same source such as systems 56 and 2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We reject the multiplicity assumption for five candidates: 57.1, 57.2, 58.1, 58.2 and 200.2 which are measured at a redshifts of 1.1041, 1.2839, 0.779, 0.78 and 4.30, respectively. No redshifts were measured for images 200.1 and 57.3. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> gives an overview of the rejected images.</p>                        <a id=\"98964840\" scrollto-destination=\"98964840\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=If~kOJgDPyEpdW0XL7ZSEkJU65cR4loyL4so3-JFavsS4JSoZ0veFLqxIcEdnWFQ4Ukp5iEuBM-3fPgBr8XrG5i4eFUmuGRv76qwc0lYNL2hTqupL46llZMsIv4KFHiS9aC5YptXt1M7Cz98mjTb9oGJ9IC6DtHsBiB1eOiEKHqNDNke1gZQgN6fB0y8mKHeSCHZBeRRuiLKxviV2G2VdAxIwqq3oWLWYHkzais4ekeuhxMEGc2S6ldApTTg~jwzMcUjqeuiPSDVXK0lTfhMojfg0dCPuXMIa-RAXXtWNiDgqdp0fSOXiJY6r~FdRVIG~34kJ1Z7zu-JKVkzHJbbrg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The three multiply imaged candidate systems downgraded to single images in this study. The middle row presents system 57, where we are able to measure redshifts of images 57.1 and 57.2. From the spectra in the right-hand panel, we can see that these two images have very different redshift values, meaning that they do not come from the same source. Finally, the bottom row presents system 58. While the redshifts of the two images are closer than those in system 57, they are still different enough that we reject them as a multiply imaged pair. The middle row presents system 57, where we are able to measure redshifts of images 57.1 and 57.2. Finally, the bottom row presents system 58. While the redshifts of the two images are closer than those in system 57, they are still different enough that we reject them as a multiply imaged pair. Each image panel is \u223c5\u2009arcsec on a side.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=If~kOJgDPyEpdW0XL7ZSEkJU65cR4loyL4so3-JFavsS4JSoZ0veFLqxIcEdnWFQ4Ukp5iEuBM-3fPgBr8XrG5i4eFUmuGRv76qwc0lYNL2hTqupL46llZMsIv4KFHiS9aC5YptXt1M7Cz98mjTb9oGJ9IC6DtHsBiB1eOiEKHqNDNke1gZQgN6fB0y8mKHeSCHZBeRRuiLKxviV2G2VdAxIwqq3oWLWYHkzais4ekeuhxMEGc2S6ldApTTg~jwzMcUjqeuiPSDVXK0lTfhMojfg0dCPuXMIa-RAXXtWNiDgqdp0fSOXiJY6r~FdRVIG~34kJ1Z7zu-JKVkzHJbbrg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The three multiply imaged candidate systems downgraded to single images in this study. Finally, the bottom row presents system 58. While the redshifts of the two images are closer than those in system 57, they are still different enough that we reject them as a multiply imaged pair. Each image panel is \u223c5\u2009arcsec on a side.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964840/stx1971fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964840\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=TM0sR47UCwPo0AqGmMdvfAeneb7Qdii4gXl5uI0AuOSbelFA5HP9-xBP7EQe3k5nNpoe~nthI6GB5EDSwq~TDbZPHZaSEBjdSU18SIrrIlpoqEQlbTMY0KWlF~X~HXaXUVOKq8W~Uzr5NiXLxCie5Bf3OVrYhCSMBngopNI24BGj17JjaPQauVNIQAHLhnNR7Lll9QS00BR2vJ-U43HlA5xibq592qfqsUCTCEglQKZvqxiaSTld8IFeOU4EICNSdiXNuavtF8zZGmODijjsNwFQ929mzL8reRQZCxJ1goxKx3jsfTFjBxDFh~SMhVnkD6IRU-J3lPceFC8ZxxlubQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964840&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The three multiply imaged candidate systems downgraded to single images in this study. The top row presents system 200, where we are only able to measure a redshift for image 200.2. Using the location of the object and its measured redshift, our model predicts that it is not multiply imaged. The middle row presents system 57, where we are able to measure redshifts of images 57.1 and 57.2. From the spectra in the right-hand panel, we can see that these two images have very different redshift values, meaning that they do not come from the same source. Finally, the bottom row presents system 58. While the redshifts of the two images are closer than those in system 57, they are still different enough that we reject them as a multiply imaged pair. Each image panel is \u223c5\u2009arcsec on a side.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In our inspection of the MUSE data cube we discovered Ly\u03b1 emitters corresponding to three new multiply imaged systems. No photometric counterpart in the <em>HST</em> images could securely be associated with their Ly\u03b1 emission (see systems 62, 63 and 64 in the list of multiple images).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=98964842 id=\"98964842\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-2>4.3.2 Reliability of multiply imaged systems</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The secure identification of multiple-image systems is key in building a robust model of the mass of the cluster. Because of the nature of lensing, constraints can only probe the total mass within an Einstein radius corresponding to the unique position and redshift of the source. Increasing the number of constraints at different positions and various redshifts thus makes it possible to map the mass distribution over the entire cluster. To maximize our coverage, we consider two categories of constraints: hard and soft.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Hard constraints occur when both the position of images and the redshift are known accurately. Thus, the mass potential parameters have to reproduce the correct position of the multiply imaged systems at the given redshift. Soft constraints occur when the position is known but not the redshift. In that case, the redshift is considered to be a free parameter and the model has to optimize the redshift that best predicts the multiple-image positions. Soft constraints introduce a large degeneracy between redshift and enclosed mass that will only be broken if a large number of such constraints are used.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to test the reliability of our multiple-image identifications, we compute an SED \u03c7<sup>2</sup> statistic to quantify the similarity of the photometry in each pair of images within a given system: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\chi ^{2}_{\\nu }=\\frac{1}{N-1} \\min _{\\alpha }\\left(\\sum \\limits _{i=1}^{N} \\frac{(f_{\\text{i}}^{\\text{A}}- \\alpha f_{\\text{i}}^{\\text{B}})^{2} }{{\\sigma _{\\text{i}}^{\\text{A}}}^{2}+ \\alpha ^{2} {\\sigma _{\\text{i}}^{\\text{B}}}^{2} }\\right)\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where <em>N</em> is the total number of filters, (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$f^{X}_{\\text{i}}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma ^{X}_{\\text{i}}$|\u2060</span>) the flux estimate and error in filter <em>i</em> for images A and B considered to compute the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. The conservation of colours between two lensed images make their photometry similar up to an overall flux ratio \u03b1 which is minimized in this equation. As shown by Mahler et\u00a0al. (in preparation) this statistic quantifies the probability of two images to come from the same sources. It shows some similarities with the approach used by Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and Hoag et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), expect for their use of colours and a normalization per pair of filters in their calculation. Combining all HFF filters, we found acceptable values for \u03c7<sup>2</sup> (0 to 3) for almost all images, with slightly higher values typically being observed for sources whose photometry is compromised by bright nearby galaxies or suffer from \u2018overdeblending\u2019.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The good \u03c7<sup>2</sup> value of system 7 (\u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u223c 1.2) promote the system to secure system and the poor agreement between the flux ratio and the predicted amplification ratio by three order of magnitude demote the counter image 10.3 to less reliable constraint.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We divide constraints into four different types of multiply imaged constraints, according to their confidence. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The most reliable constraints, dubbed <em>gold</em>, consists of hard constraints (i.e. having spectroscopic redshifts). <em>Gold</em> systems do not include counter images without a spectroscopic redshift, except for system 2 which has a very distinct morphology. 83 images belonging to 29 systems are marked as <em>gold</em>.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The second set of constraints, dubbed <em>silver</em>, are the most photometrically convincing images and systems in addition of <em>gold</em> constraints, following mostly the (unofficial) selection of FFs challenge modellers. By adding 22 images and 9 systems, this brings the total number of constraints to 105 images over 38 systems.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The third set, dubbed <em>bronze</em>, includes less reliable constraints. The <em>bronze</em> set contains 143 images of 51 systems.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fourth set, dubbed <em>copper</em>, include images 3.3, 8.3, 14.3, 36.3, 37.3 and 38.3 because they were previously in disagreement among previous studies (see Lam et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a> as example of disagreement). <em>Copper</em> set of constraints include as well all the remaining counter images and systems reported bringing the total number of images to 188 belonging to 60 systems.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The multiple images used in this study are shown in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. The full list of multiply images is provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>. Spectral identification of each gold image is presented in Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec10\"></span><a href=\"#sec10\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">C</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98964849\" scrollto-destination=\"98964849\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=H7L5A7JA1Q3UWiMTDHWxQpVtyHXVh18-a0HQYIT19yHF5wXcf8Gv2Pkm-LjQk4i1eug4VZ8apYm2gqrw8DCxyu7N0H6ez9WOUi7D7kvluhFyezDEKFyFJSoa7W09M6SBC~BGA-oVo1OZ~CNW5YnS1VWtwMbvaoMLwCg9mO6RVoL1qTz1jJuSlFqSQWcHaP2VN8Rmi3pgiwAmpaWfSUTeAL6LPQ3wjv9pkJ2gFLMC6JV~IdNr3oZkT2hqbPc9HF11jQ6u~xFxsvlaxIaOn2ljvrt1u2K-3FkSBSP0DSgEt29P5zl-iYzlMzbQsYb~klbwOqaDX~d7gwoMa4ThB11TAg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The gold, silver, bronze and copper circles match different sets of constraints called gold, silver, bronze and copper. Each of the constraints matches its corresponding colour. To avoid any mismatching, silver constraints appear bluer and copper constraints appear pinker. Each of the constraints matches its corresponding colour. To avoid any mismatching, <em>silver</em> constraints appear bluer and <em>copper</em> constraints appear pinker. See Table\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> for details.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=H7L5A7JA1Q3UWiMTDHWxQpVtyHXVh18-a0HQYIT19yHF5wXcf8Gv2Pkm-LjQk4i1eug4VZ8apYm2gqrw8DCxyu7N0H6ez9WOUi7D7kvluhFyezDEKFyFJSoa7W09M6SBC~BGA-oVo1OZ~CNW5YnS1VWtwMbvaoMLwCg9mO6RVoL1qTz1jJuSlFqSQWcHaP2VN8Rmi3pgiwAmpaWfSUTeAL6LPQ3wjv9pkJ2gFLMC6JV~IdNr3oZkT2hqbPc9HF11jQ6u~xFxsvlaxIaOn2ljvrt1u2K-3FkSBSP0DSgEt29P5zl-iYzlMzbQsYb~klbwOqaDX~d7gwoMa4ThB11TAg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The gold, silver, bronze and copper circles match different sets of constraints called gold, silver, bronze and copper. Each of the constraints matches its corresponding colour. To avoid any mismatching, silver constraints appear bluer and copper constraints appear pinker. See Table\u2009A1 for details.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964849/stx1971fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964849\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=mbo3yIojlwiTMiKA93P7iendGpt-r7o4EUJ9F7K-IPqKabJXOSSoM0Qy1rMjysVtQIOQ6WugPwmHJ5MgaDw49D2K4dKn8t3JB2~PvAspLkr-wiNRZUAxGT5rM-ESmyrmXASfhmaQqa37wvzsbIOzLmfAgs71TQK3grw6rmWlB4ySOGzk1wU4mXpChdmSIa0GuDqZhjixNzSO3K7oLSXKTLrzhYW4G0ky4anvrJ~dA0DpGd3KnZBpqqztiWKRozv9SkXHcKShU0wP1LrMWsQ7VLxadp1wpSTifsRBh8bbSJXIVZsbaA8F4r1Igxomda~7SDHFQaZ0tcTMqIJIHdyJwA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964849&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The gold, silver, bronze and copper circles match different sets of constraints called <em>gold</em>, <em>silver</em>, <em>bronze</em> and <em>copper</em>. Each of the constraints matches its corresponding colour. To avoid any mismatching, <em>silver</em> constraints appear bluer and <em>copper</em> constraints appear pinker. See Table\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> for details.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964850 id=\"98964850\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 LENS MODELLING RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we construct lens models and describe their properties, along with the details of individual strong-lensing features.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964852 id=\"98964852\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Mass distribution in the cluster core</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To investigate improvements on currently known mass models, we test several assumptions using a series of different model configurations. We quantitatively compare the quality of models with two criteria. The first one is the rms, which describes how well the model reproduces the positions of the constraints. The second one is the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) which is a statistical measurement based on the model Likelihood <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}$|\u2060</span>, penalized by the number of free parameters <em>k</em> and the number of constraints <em>n</em>: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{\\rm BIC} = -2 \\times \\log (\\mathcal {L}) + k \\times \\log (n),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>The rms will give indication good indication of the global distance between your predicted images position in comparison with the measured one. Thus, we seek to reduce the rms as much as possible. The BIC will quantify the balance between the improvement of the model likelihood and the addition of parameters and constraints. Thus, we seek to see the best improvement of the likelihood while keeping the lowest BIC value possible.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For our initial model, we start with a parametrization similar to Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), namely: two DM clumps representing cluster-scale potentials and two small-scale background galaxies (MUSE<sub>9778</sub> and MUSE<sub>7257</sub>), in addition to identified cluster members (246). We also optimize the two primary BCGs separately from the mass-to-light scaling relation (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>). While the Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) model achieves an rms of 0.69\u2009arcsec, our model \u2013 which includes 24 new systems with secure redshifts from MUSE and Keck data \u2013 has an rms of 1.87\u2009arcsec and a BIC\u00a0=\u00a04893. The higher rms is expected: by increasing the number of spectroscopic constraints, the model can no longer adjust the redshifts of these systems to better fit the model. However systems 5 and 47 (as defined in Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) contribute the most to the rms (system 5: rms=3.24\u2009arcsec, system 47 rms=1.71\u2009arcsec). Since there is a chance these objects might be incorrectly identified and because they affect mainly the northern part of the cluster core we temporarily remove these two systems for our next test.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In an attempt to improve the model further, we add a third cluster-scale clump \u223c20\u2009arcsec north of the northern BCG, free to vary in position. We choose this location due to the significant number of cluster galaxies in the area. After running two models, one with and one without the third clump, the resulting global rms is 0.77\u2009arcsec in both cases , whereas the two clumps hypothesis has a BIC = 332 which is slightly lower than the three clumps BIC = 362. Note that at this stage systems 5 and 47 are still not included as constraints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, we next test the same assumptions but we revise the positions of systems 5 and 47 by adjusting them to the centroid of the Lyman-\u03b1 emission. Additionally, thanks to the MUSE blind identification of the extended Lyman-\u03b1 emission of these two sources, we are able to add two new constraints: systems 105 and 147 which function as separate substructures of systems 5 and 47, respectively. The mean rms (BIC) for the two different configurations increases from 0.77 to 0.86\u2009arcsec (from 332 to 419) for the two-clump assumption and from 0.77 to 0.96\u2009arcsec (from 362 to 511) for the three-clump assumption. This significant improvement on the models, compared to the initial one, is consistent with the observation of a diffuse gaseous component around the two galaxies sources of systems 5 and 47. The study of the physical properties of all background sources behind A2744 will be presented in a forthcoming paper (De la Vieuville et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the addition of a third clump at best leaves the rms unchanged, we favour the simpler two-clump model moving forward. At the same time, we keep the new constraint configuration of systems 5/105 and 47/147, since this reduces the rms from the original model. Differences in models are shown in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98964858\" scrollto-destination=\"98964858\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=c82xiwv0l1JUuGsbhVH-IkVsMVUEeGOSZO3sma7Dtbs3LOOuCVMhpKFSIHwMO7fG14af6wbm84VydXN9jhrJU8zLFovP7vGM7oUMNO6vR2OJjn~oox~Sn-3W-De3RMs0anD6g5aS73Z0kdBfztfgf2yQltjAnf2R1Mj2nTCXkFtt0MeIyxojV1Exmtfw3hxQVCQrquqNLzG5ImaYMEB-Pum6IiMiAfB3L2c6HsJyFsGM08J5rvvsGHYaz3Xt4qND3kmK~dPVOzBWUPW4T3zzkL2ymQl0qrz2LexyY7gmpPvW4RXBelCIACYLtSne76xAxTj0jWJE7j5Lcx6O-Qat2w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Differences between models based on the assumptions developed in Section\u00a05. The blue contour shows the Lyman-\u03b1 emission at the redshift of systems 5, 105, 47 and 147 (z\u00a0=\u00a04.0225). The orange, red and green lines show the tangential critical curve at the same redshift for three different models. While all models use the same parametrization for the mass components, each makes a different assumption about systems 5 and 47. As a reference, the orange line traces the critical curve when the two systems are removed from the model entirely. Conversely, the red line shows the critical curve assuming the previous constraint configuration: namely, that systems 5 and 47 are each an individual multiply imaged object. Finally, the green line represents the critical curve measured when system 5 and 47 are both divided in two distinct components (system 5\u21925 and 105 and system 47\u219247 and 147). This new configuration better matches the observed Lyman-\u03b1 emission.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964858/stx1971fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964858\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=aCdESzx38~8~-5nrJIyp9EvTW2ICxziEyTzBUdAyOj5fIsHYfpnxHTC7mVzHEgqGjta1KNNni~AxZPaS5HPxB0VfXfacKfLBOe4KkfToP-pfAzpx4WbwNZmQlSbN77jJYkmD8lAWvBbeZvJTX3ivYdnI~1tmvJiLTapHhGY74tZyNcy~RlsDcO6ifYPTjMNtRUIvXOzcCmnQG6zPsVkmUts8iEEl-Vwr9cfrt3AS2IwyWzX3Tk7zSbWA4NIgKIpzG819CApmNEkDe0UJaU0FmMOvFooGVhvmb8azyPTGgnBKzi0ckdaBcuq2Y4h7qFXswUNa2CEbAXPg1cfdas9yfw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964858&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Differences between models based on the assumptions developed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. The blue contour shows the Lyman-\u03b1 emission at the redshift of systems 5, 105, 47 and 147 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a04.0225). The orange, red and green lines show the tangential critical curve at the same redshift for three different models. While all models use the same parametrization for the mass components, each makes a different assumption about systems 5 and 47. As a reference, the orange line traces the critical curve when the two systems are removed from the model entirely. Conversely, the red line shows the critical curve assuming the previous constraint configuration: namely, that systems 5 and 47 are each an individual multiply imaged object. Finally, the green line represents the critical curve measured when system 5 and 47 are both divided in two distinct components (system 5\u21925 and 105 and system 47\u219247 and 147). This new configuration better matches the observed Lyman-\u03b1 emission.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=c82xiwv0l1JUuGsbhVH-IkVsMVUEeGOSZO3sma7Dtbs3LOOuCVMhpKFSIHwMO7fG14af6wbm84VydXN9jhrJU8zLFovP7vGM7oUMNO6vR2OJjn~oox~Sn-3W-De3RMs0anD6g5aS73Z0kdBfztfgf2yQltjAnf2R1Mj2nTCXkFtt0MeIyxojV1Exmtfw3hxQVCQrquqNLzG5ImaYMEB-Pum6IiMiAfB3L2c6HsJyFsGM08J5rvvsGHYaz3Xt4qND3kmK~dPVOzBWUPW4T3zzkL2ymQl0qrz2LexyY7gmpPvW4RXBelCIACYLtSne76xAxTj0jWJE7j5Lcx6O-Qat2w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Differences between models based on the assumptions developed in Section\u00a05. The orange, red and green lines show the tangential critical curve at the same redshift for three different models. While all models use the same parametrization for the mass components, each makes a different assumption about systems 5 and 47. As a reference, the orange line traces the critical curve when the two systems are removed from the model entirely. Conversely, the red line shows the critical curve assuming the previous constraint configuration: namely, that systems 5 and 47 are each an individual multiply imaged object. Finally, the green line represents the critical curve measured when system 5 and 47 are both divided in two distinct components (system 5\u21925 and 105 and system 47\u219247 and 147). This new configuration better matches the observed Lyman-\u03b1 emission.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964858/stx1971fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964858\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=aCdESzx38~8~-5nrJIyp9EvTW2ICxziEyTzBUdAyOj5fIsHYfpnxHTC7mVzHEgqGjta1KNNni~AxZPaS5HPxB0VfXfacKfLBOe4KkfToP-pfAzpx4WbwNZmQlSbN77jJYkmD8lAWvBbeZvJTX3ivYdnI~1tmvJiLTapHhGY74tZyNcy~RlsDcO6ifYPTjMNtRUIvXOzcCmnQG6zPsVkmUts8iEEl-Vwr9cfrt3AS2IwyWzX3Tk7zSbWA4NIgKIpzG819CApmNEkDe0UJaU0FmMOvFooGVhvmb8azyPTGgnBKzi0ckdaBcuq2Y4h7qFXswUNa2CEbAXPg1cfdas9yfw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964858&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Differences between models based on the assumptions developed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. The blue contour shows the Lyman-\u03b1 emission at the redshift of systems 5, 105, 47 and 147 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a04.0225). The orange, red and green lines show the tangential critical curve at the same redshift for three different models. While all models use the same parametrization for the mass components, each makes a different assumption about systems 5 and 47. As a reference, the orange line traces the critical curve when the two systems are removed from the model entirely. Conversely, the red line shows the critical curve assuming the previous constraint configuration: namely, that systems 5 and 47 are each an individual multiply imaged object. Finally, the green line represents the critical curve measured when system 5 and 47 are both divided in two distinct components (system 5\u21925 and 105 and system 47\u219247 and 147). This new configuration better matches the observed Lyman-\u03b1 emission.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964859 id=\"98964859\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Influence of the cluster environment</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The weak-lensing analysis of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> reported the identification of six cluster substructures at large radii (\u223c700\u2009kpc) with a significance level above 5\u03c3. We expect these complex, large-scale structures to have an effect on the location of multiple images in the cluster core.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To first order the influence from these mass substructures can be approximated as a shear field. To test this possibility, we include the influence of an external (constant) shear field in our model, described by the following two parameters: the strength of the shear \u03b3 and the position angle \u03b8. We use a broad uniform prior on the external shear: 0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u03b3\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.2 for the strength and \u221290\u00b0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u03b8\u00a0&lt;\u00a090\u00b0 for the angle. The resulting model rms is 0.78\u2009arcsec and BIC = 384 (compared to 0.86\u2009arcsec and BIC = 419 before) with best-fitting parameters \u03b8\u00a0=\u00a0\u221236\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u2009deg and a strength \u03b3\u00a0=\u00a00.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01. The effect of the external shear is global on the cluster core and not specifically targeted to a single location. From the analysis of the posterior probability distribution of each parameter, we notice a small correlation for each of the external shear parameters. The shear angle slightly correlates with the core radius and velocity dispersion parameters both from the southern DM clumps whereas the shear strength slightly anticorrelates with the two same parameters. These small correlations will not affect our results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While adding an external shear improves our mass model, in some ways it is not physical, because it does not rely on specific masses. Therefore, we construct an alternative model which includes the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> substructures as individual mass components. We exclude the substructure on the west side (labelled as Wbis in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>) because it is behind the cluster. We model the other clumps using dPIE potentials. Because the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> weak-lensing analysis does not provide analytic parameters for mass profiles, we place priors on the dPIE parameters. In order to make the model clumps recreate the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> total mass values as closely as possible, we look for the best scaling relation parameters (\u03c3*, r<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm cut}^*$|\u2060</span>) matching the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> masses for each substructure based on the following criteria: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the enclosed mass in a radius of 150\u2009kpc from the clump centre,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the enclosed mass in a radius of 250\u2009kpc from the clump, and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the overall smoothness of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> cluster mass contours</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to the different amount of light associated with the substructures as reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>, we separated the six potentials in two different scaling relations. To maintain the same number of parameters as the model with an external shear, we only optimize the values of \u03c3* of the two scaling relations. The resulting masses of the clumps are reported in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, following the nomenclature from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>. The resulting rms is 0.67\u2009arcsec\u2009which is comparable to the rms of the model including external shear (0.78\u2009arcsec). We will discuss the comparison of these two models in more details in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98964864\" scrollto-destination=\"98964864\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the masses of the individual mass clumps used in this study and in Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> shows the location of each of the clumps.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Clump<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>This study<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>M(10<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{13}$|\u2060</span>) M<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$ _{{\\odot }}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>M(10<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{13}$|\u2060</span>) M<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$ _{{\\odot }}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98964864\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964865 id=\"98964865\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Dependence on the constraints</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To this point, we have tested several model parametrizations while limiting our constraints to the <em>gold</em> set. We now reverse the process and look into the effect of using other sets of constraints (<em>silver, bronze</em> and <em>copper</em>, see\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3.2</a>), while keeping a fixed set of parameters. For these tests we use the model parametrization which includes substructures in the outskirts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each set of constraints, we optimize the model and the best-fitting parameters are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. There is an apparent improvement on the rms from the <em>gold</em>-constrained (0.67\u2009arcsec) to the <em>silver</em>-constrained (0.59\u2009arcsec) model. However, the higher BIC (400) of the <em>silver</em>-constrained compared to the <em>gold</em>-constrained model (332) suggests that the penalty of adding new constraints outweighs the improvement in the fit, despite the lower rms. In other words, the BIC indicates that the additional photometric candidates do not bring new information to the constraints that already exist in the <em>gold</em> sample.</p>                        <a id=\"98964868\" scrollto-destination=\"98964868\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens models and best-fitting parameters for each dPIE clump. From left to right: central coordinates (measured relative to the position (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a000<sup>h</sup>14<sup>m</sup>20.7022<sup>s</sup>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u221230\u00b024<sup>\u0384</sup>00.6264<sup>\u2033</sup>), ellipticity (defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semi-major and semi-minor axes of the ellipse), position angle, central velocity dispersion, cut and core radii. Quantities within brackets are fixed parameters in the model. DM1 and DM2 refer to the large-scale DM halo while BCG1 and BCG2 refer to the first and second brightest galaxy in the cluster core. NorthGal and SouthGal are two background galaxies that are projected into the lens plane to be modelled as they could influence locally the position of multiple images. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> clumps A and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> clumps B divide the six cluster substructures detected in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> into two groups : clumps A (N, NW and S3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>) have bright luminous counterparts, while clumps B (S1, S2 and S4 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>) have faint luminous counterparts.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model name<span class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98964868\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens models and best-fitting parameters for each dPIE clump. From left to right: central coordinates (measured relative to the position (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a000<sup>h</sup>14<sup>m</sup>20.7022<sup>s</sup>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u221230\u00b024<sup>\u0384</sup>00.6264<sup>\u2033</sup>), ellipticity (defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semi-major and semi-minor axes of the ellipse), position angle, central velocity dispersion, cut and core radii. Quantities within brackets are fixed parameters in the model. DM1 and DM2 refer to the large-scale DM halo while BCG1 and BCG2 refer to the first and second brightest galaxy in the cluster core. NorthGal and SouthGal are two background galaxies that are projected into the lens plane to be modelled as they could influence locally the position of multiple images. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> clumps A and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> clumps B divide the six cluster substructures detected in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> into two groups : clumps A (N, NW and S3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>) have bright luminous counterparts, while clumps B (S1, S2 and S4 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>) have faint luminous counterparts.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model name<span
