(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) are optimized during the minimization procedure. The colour codes for the minimal distance between two images from the same systems whereas symbols show how many images compose the systems.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=XNki~lx6WpycivC~vMmYqPXzrcpC6kxTmPcCK4bNIX5vnosLhfAlfBDhNdQoZ3LeKoj2Zwpf7Iv3xI7tw6T~2Id74wLxn7cS2q~tHhRChQdUpyQ48sXREtxHR9AB1HUPeiPK38cJSL1gpf-Mt5pN6RZ9oaWVYYFrIOqArjk6gDnHQN2EVa8aHhhJpiie~2VqsKq5i~bDHSSmMU8AU957wXk2wtZo54KDWEX2TKKoJkU98O1BcVGIG-2dOPVFaLDFCEd~hXMVP9UWSuopyMbcMwYdORl-YJA9LhAohvQRQCZpq28IfqsI4bmsjCUZFn53aPtwMVrhy74brvxGxec5fA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between model-predicted redshifts and the new spectroscopic measurements. The models used for prediction is based on the fiducial model (mass clumps in the outskirts plus gold sample), but newly measured redshifts compared to Wang et\u00a0al. (2015) are optimized during the minimization procedure. The colour codes for the minimal distance between two images from the same systems whereas symbols show how many images compose the systems.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964897/stx1971fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964897\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=tlBwdvvHWdKniKR1NePzYpmU9H4eLiryzga2xS6WjTYA1eP3j8jDO-LfkAuzfvNl2tM-PwZ9UfUSMuHM089dOpn4qeWWYyv0Kxyi2xcXz4QmErImYSj~kYURXcZltG0bGsUBzduEAFNfY3OOFyhbGdV3IRyk7fec2eU0BGCrN57GUbcgrlRN3gKMa3juLEZHbJjReCd7ph7jLJS-cNTDO6CJOGOiJ-7rPBcdG5MX9GUU6dCtBUwHB4GRhhDPRRMtUAgf0qLJRZacfaO1fXXsm02zmZTsOd2LIIjxKDwF9AEkOhmd0sUWHBiPbRr1s~rkWCUIW~7K-aH99f4uecPY3Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964897&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between model-predicted redshifts and the new spectroscopic measurements. The models used for prediction is based on the fiducial model (mass clumps in the outskirts plus <em>gold</em> sample), but newly measured redshifts compared to Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) are optimized during the minimization procedure. The colour codes for the minimal distance between two images from the same systems whereas symbols show how many images compose the systems.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, we investigate differences in the 2D mass distribution between the two models, to see if they are larger than the level of statistical uncertainty. Globally, enclosed within large radii, the total mass is almost unchanged. However, we do notice differences at smaller scales, so we probe these local discrepancies to see if the significance of this signal is important. To do so, we compute the difference in \u03ba (convergence) between the two models divided by the standard deviation of the modified (free-redshift) model. This is shown in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>. From the figure, we see that systematic variations in the very centre and at the outer limit of the core are in opposite directions but both have magnitudes higher than two times \u03c3stat, a significant source of systematic variation. By doing this, we note that we are only probing the systematics due to the addition of new redshift information.</p>                        <a id=\"98964899\" scrollto-destination=\"98964899\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=G5JY4Ln0AzRzVIdtXjhRUAbLVLZWKs1WJ4vrB7Y2BH0h~F8Sh~WHTZ3a3hFLAM9tu4-HIrZ13OA8trAPdYK4~taPa7Vss~1w3KKYh5XC4ZJL3wAYhrMQmzgfyz9uvUVraF8LBvGUW-lvejEQxyEdxzqMMi1ckCWET0be8mr2ihPZ8NbxcODdRLWQwHt3M4jzKVD6F5c99NRDwG7~poWu5v5AJEWvxJQMEYQM7TozAn-vT-RexpINYbNMEqLzt4oCaHvzRkRggtMtR9MeuVCKEkWGU7cRJ~h-~iYgeQQAVk9jXn078SX9NgQxMzhBbvvzh-L6z0toDjld4BaRo0zwtw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relative variation in the 2D surface mass distribution, in units of the statistical uncertainty \u03c3stat, between two models with (fiducial) and without the MUSE spectroscopic constraints. These maps can be related to systematics uncertainties, with negative values referring to underestimated mass and positive value overestimated mass. The green box represents the 2\u2009arcmin\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02\u2009arcmin MUSE-mosaic FoV. This highlights the benefit of a deep and wide spectroscopic coverage such as this study.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964899/stx1971fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964899\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=xzWfLtbezkpwIRPPYKa2dNabidENGs5CSxi2RLHQDLH66PskdTGBaZzuE1nmD76vBI2UVMRcbo1yNuj9cHhaGNWEHgQxKsKjMfsOudyWusne2wc-nfUa3K4wImlAv3NrVVc2pUwCnvivSvo~LhQdR6b7SLFhbT0n2IyZtIBSmH-tBRpzIP5~1KZ9O8apoYdeRFOeObZNCl1DELuNVn-COXSDO6QDz0HqgPyjBzH-FVjxwdYIIYhNiCCcL3m7ZuycM4NolkGwZRohNazHOucJMN2JdAotPDwEHWLPn-AkZWpzolhDnmkpD-GKmZLh-aQSZvadhFds2WRoY-LDzsEtSQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964899&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative variation in the 2D surface mass distribution, in units of the statistical uncertainty \u03c3stat, between two models with (fiducial) and without the MUSE spectroscopic constraints. These maps can be related to systematics uncertainties, with negative values referring to underestimated mass and positive value overestimated mass. The green box represents the 2\u2009arcmin\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02\u2009arcmin MUSE-mosaic FoV. This highlights the benefit of a deep and wide spectroscopic coverage such as this study.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=G5JY4Ln0AzRzVIdtXjhRUAbLVLZWKs1WJ4vrB7Y2BH0h~F8Sh~WHTZ3a3hFLAM9tu4-HIrZ13OA8trAPdYK4~taPa7Vss~1w3KKYh5XC4ZJL3wAYhrMQmzgfyz9uvUVraF8LBvGUW-lvejEQxyEdxzqMMi1ckCWET0be8mr2ihPZ8NbxcODdRLWQwHt3M4jzKVD6F5c99NRDwG7~poWu5v5AJEWvxJQMEYQM7TozAn-vT-RexpINYbNMEqLzt4oCaHvzRkRggtMtR9MeuVCKEkWGU7cRJ~h-~iYgeQQAVk9jXn078SX9NgQxMzhBbvvzh-L6z0toDjld4BaRo0zwtw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relative variation in the 2D surface mass distribution, in units of the statistical uncertainty \u03c3stat, between two models with (fiducial) and without the MUSE spectroscopic constraints. These maps can be related to systematics uncertainties, with negative values referring to underestimated mass and positive value overestimated mass. The green box represents the 2\u2009arcmin\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02\u2009arcmin MUSE-mosaic FoV. This highlights the benefit of a deep and wide spectroscopic coverage such as this study.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964899/stx1971fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964899\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=xzWfLtbezkpwIRPPYKa2dNabidENGs5CSxi2RLHQDLH66PskdTGBaZzuE1nmD76vBI2UVMRcbo1yNuj9cHhaGNWEHgQxKsKjMfsOudyWusne2wc-nfUa3K4wImlAv3NrVVc2pUwCnvivSvo~LhQdR6b7SLFhbT0n2IyZtIBSmH-tBRpzIP5~1KZ9O8apoYdeRFOeObZNCl1DELuNVn-COXSDO6QDz0HqgPyjBzH-FVjxwdYIIYhNiCCcL3m7ZuycM4NolkGwZRohNazHOucJMN2JdAotPDwEHWLPn-AkZWpzolhDnmkpD-GKmZLh-aQSZvadhFds2WRoY-LDzsEtSQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964899&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative variation in the 2D surface mass distribution, in units of the statistical uncertainty \u03c3stat, between two models with (fiducial) and without the MUSE spectroscopic constraints. These maps can be related to systematics uncertainties, with negative values referring to underestimated mass and positive value overestimated mass. The green box represents the 2\u2009arcmin\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02\u2009arcmin MUSE-mosaic FoV. This highlights the benefit of a deep and wide spectroscopic coverage such as this study.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Secondly, we compare the mass density profiles of the models when changing the sets of constraints, keeping a fixed parametrization (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a>). This comparison can be done within the cluster core (<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0200\u2009kpc) between the <em>gold</em>-, <em>silver</em>- and <em>bronze</em>-constrained models which have a similar rms overall. We find that by including these less reliable constraints, the <em>silver</em>-constrained model gives systematically higher mass densities by \u223c2\u2009per\u2009cent (2 \u03c3<sub>stat</sub>) compared to the <em>gold</em> model, while the <em>bronze</em>-constrained model is \u223c3\u2009per\u2009cent higher (3 \u03c3<sub>stat</sub>). This test highlights a relative systematic in the mass distribution. Specifically, we see that including less reliable systems can alter the measured mass distribution. This is mainly due to two reasons. First, by adding extra (misidentified) multiple image constraints, the model will add additional mass where it is not needed. Secondly, by adding extra (correct) multiple image constraints, the model becomes more sensitive to additional regions of space which can contain, for example, local mass substructures.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thirdly, we can compare the results of different model parametrization, this time keeping the constraints fixed to the <em>gold</em> set, as in Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2</a>. Specifically, we compare discrepancies between the external shear model and the outskirts mass clump model. At a distance of 200\u2009kpc from the cluster centre, we measure a typical variation of \u223c6\u2009per\u2009cent between the integrated mass profiles of the two models (upper panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>), giving another estimate of systemic uncertainty on the mass profiles.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similarly, we can compare our models to other HFF models which do not follow the same parametric approach. It is not fair to compare modelling techniques here because latest published models (v3) do not include the same number of spectroscopic constraints. However, it is interesting to compare mass profiles from previous models with our more robust models, probing the scatter due to their lack of redshifts. From Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, we can clearly see in the top panel that our fiducial model in orange is one the most massive models. More interestingly, due to the redshift contribution there is a significant reduction of the mass in the inner core, between 20 and 100\u2009kpc, by 10\u2009per\u2009cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, we can see that the CATS (v3) model mass profile is significantly higher than other models in the cluster core, while this is no longer the case in our fiducial model. We note that a similar discrepancy was also reported by Priewe et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) as well as Bouwens et\u00a0al. (in preparation) on the CATS (v3) model regarding systematically higher magnification values than other v3 models. Indeed, systematic uncertainties on the mass profiles also reflect on the magnification of background sources, especially for high values of \u03bc. Compared with our fiducial (<em>gold</em> constrained) model, the magnification of a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06 source typically vary by 5\u20136\u2009per\u2009cent in the low magnification region (\u03bc\u00a0&lt;\u00a010) and between 10 and 20\u2009per\u2009cent in the high magnification region (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a010), when using the <em>silver</em>- and <em>bronze</em>-constrained models instead.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we can look at the magnified supernova (SN) HFF14 Tom (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a000<sup>h</sup>14<sup>m</sup>17.87<sup>s</sup>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a030\u00b023<sup>\u0384</sup>59.7<sup>\u2033</sup>) discovered at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.3457\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 behind A2744 (Rodney et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). As a Type Ia SN, the intrinsic luminosity of SN Tom is known from its light curve. However, its observed luminosity is 0.77\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15 mag brighter than expected (as compared to known unlensed Type Ia SNe at similar redshift), implying a lensing magnification of \u03bc<sub>obs</sub> = 2.03\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.29. Therefore, rather than using the SN magnification as a constraint, we instead set it as a benchmark value to be derived from each model. Our fiducial model gives a value \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a02.149\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.029. On the other hand, the model including external shear gives a magnification of 1.789\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.045, but is probably lacking some mass (and magnification) at this radius. While these two values are significantly different from one another, they both fall within the overall uncertainty envelope as defined by Rodney et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, which is another probe of systematics. A comparison of our magnifications values to those derived from other studies can be seen in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>. Here again, large-scale differences between models are likely due to systematics.</p>                        <a id=\"98964905\" scrollto-destination=\"98964905\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=T0o~sHuv6tRv5oAxJ-pj27Jb0hQKMN2ctIEHvkaaF9R-j5b4NsTWK-1DJck2EnhenyTcSht-BSZyaWiJRXhkcexnj6vZ078B9WINz1xGotlIfpwuuyXu81g5Ff8sT3VFs~5S3xNH4ssM3XLoMHpUmLsoVeVwHv4RQyxd6qTD7l5P213j8gcP-VysLiuSGMIt26ahoNcnwbiehXfQ-7WWCSAanpys6yZ2~3BKN7WdxyUZI7LnU9iFyqSqiVpUj-hE3wGSv3mLCiz801yKi7L5t7gPRB6oFfiOTC9bZikENVQ9pX65FKE4f9oRKHgiXPrZ9XZ9QzMQ4rKPS2GqLGEunA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the observed lensing magnification for the SNe HFF14Tom to predictions from lens models. The vertical black line shows the constraints from the SNe reported in Rodney et\u00a0al. (2015), the shaded region marking the total uncertainty. Markers with horizontal error bars show the median magnification and 68\u2009per\u2009cent confidence region from each models.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964905/stx1971fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964905\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=Q09UVSHMmCHxoErf9Ig65jIzOXjPruGkQOt7PoriPxhmy4XOWiSuJ80LzYAinN2TqIkQMRruuMQLTWD1DhJVooJsps55KxUeuAbHTBuwbckCrFtf3sMG6tHfEzGPQZ89SmKz3~NqPZBXREOSCb4fzPa5htt-kZjcIiW0s9GRV3UmlZxie7MB-p5USC-nVHbqrHLJF~1aVg~G7eJx9iYQeHDPR4mobvlETZacYaRPxInlihjVwOEFPnt0PFzm-sA5cqggHag~5QSbaZ7LoWlrUqDgmhszeMHpoDh9akO4TubmcNDMpl4ZiTv09Nxts2RrJcCjj695fwHpNeqrLwULpA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964905&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the observed lensing magnification for the SNe HFF14Tom to predictions from lens models. The vertical black line shows the constraints from the SNe reported in Rodney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the shaded region marking the total uncertainty. Markers with horizontal error bars show the median magnification and 68\u2009per\u2009cent confidence region from each models.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=T0o~sHuv6tRv5oAxJ-pj27Jb0hQKMN2ctIEHvkaaF9R-j5b4NsTWK-1DJck2EnhenyTcSht-BSZyaWiJRXhkcexnj6vZ078B9WINz1xGotlIfpwuuyXu81g5Ff8sT3VFs~5S3xNH4ssM3XLoMHpUmLsoVeVwHv4RQyxd6qTD7l5P213j8gcP-VysLiuSGMIt26ahoNcnwbiehXfQ-7WWCSAanpys6yZ2~3BKN7WdxyUZI7LnU9iFyqSqiVpUj-hE3wGSv3mLCiz801yKi7L5t7gPRB6oFfiOTC9bZikENVQ9pX65FKE4f9oRKHgiXPrZ9XZ9QzMQ4rKPS2GqLGEunA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the observed lensing magnification for the SNe HFF14Tom to predictions from lens models. The vertical black line shows the constraints from the SNe reported in Rodney et\u00a0al. (2015), the shaded region marking the total uncertainty. Markers with horizontal error bars show the median magnification and 68\u2009per\u2009cent confidence region from each models.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964905/stx1971fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964905\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=Q09UVSHMmCHxoErf9Ig65jIzOXjPruGkQOt7PoriPxhmy4XOWiSuJ80LzYAinN2TqIkQMRruuMQLTWD1DhJVooJsps55KxUeuAbHTBuwbckCrFtf3sMG6tHfEzGPQZ89SmKz3~NqPZBXREOSCb4fzPa5htt-kZjcIiW0s9GRV3UmlZxie7MB-p5USC-nVHbqrHLJF~1aVg~G7eJx9iYQeHDPR4mobvlETZacYaRPxInlihjVwOEFPnt0PFzm-sA5cqggHag~5QSbaZ7LoWlrUqDgmhszeMHpoDh9akO4TubmcNDMpl4ZiTv09Nxts2RrJcCjj695fwHpNeqrLwULpA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964905&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the observed lensing magnification for the SNe HFF14Tom to predictions from lens models. The vertical black line shows the constraints from the SNe reported in Rodney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the shaded region marking the total uncertainty. Markers with horizontal error bars show the median magnification and 68\u2009per\u2009cent confidence region from each models.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964906 id=\"98964906\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we use ultradeep imaging data from the HFF program in combination with spectroscopic data from the VLT/MUSE to build a new strong-lensing mass model for the HFF cluster A2744. Our main conclusions are as follows: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thanks to the 18.5\u2009h of MUSE coverage, we perform a spectroscopic analysis and construct a redshift catalogue of a total of 514 objects (414 new identifications), including 326 background sources and 156 cluster members. The cluster members largely fall into two distinct groups, matching the velocities of the two large-scale structures found by Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). We note that many of the galaxies detected in Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) are measured at significantly larger radii from the cluster core than the MUSE coverage.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We review every multiple image recorded in previous studies, spectroscopically confirming 78 of them and adding 8 new images. We grade the other multiple images based on their photometry and their compatibility with our lens modelling.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thanks to the numerous constraints our modelling successfully includes the impact of neighbouring substructures found by the weak-lensing analysis of Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), mainly through their shear effect on the images.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overall our fiducial mass model, only constrained with spectroscopic redshifts, gives a statistical error \u223c1\u2009per\u2009cent on the mass profile in the cluster core. By testing the dependence on the choice of constraints (3\u2009per\u2009cent relative systematic uncertainties) and the parametrization of the model (6\u2009per\u2009cent relative systematic uncertainties), we find that our fiducial model error might suffer from a relative systematic uncertainty of up to \u223c9\u2009per\u2009cent on the mass profile in the multiply imaged region.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We estimate the level of systematic error from the addition of new redshifts identified by MUSE to be up to \u223c2.5 \u03c3<sub>stat</sub>, lowering the mass in the cluster core while increasing the mass in the outer part.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the background SN Ia Tomas (Rodney et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) as a test on our magnification estimates and find a good agreement between the observed lensing magnification (2.03\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.29), and the magnification predicted by our fiducial model (2.149\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.029).</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the end the deep spectroscopic coverage of this cluster allows us to improve the overall accuracy of the lensing reconstruction, mainly by placing an unprecedented number of constraints on the mass profile of the cluster core. This illustrates the usefulness of obtaining deep, complete spectroscopic coverage of lensing clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass models, as well as the associated mass and magnification maps, have been publicly released as CATS (v4) through the FFs mass modelling challenge, and the resulting spectroscopy was shared among the other lensing teams. Accurate magnification estimates will be particularly useful for high-redshift studies constraining the faint-end slope of the luminosity function (Atek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bouwens et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to previous lensing works, the large increase in the number of multiple systems with confirmed redshifts sets a new challenge which we believe will help the overall lensing community to better understand the complexity of this cluster. The parametric approach used in our models can reproduce all strong-lensing constraints with a good rms (typically 0.6\u2009arcsec), but ultimately new techniques will be needed to fully account for all the strong-lensing information and further improve the quality of the models. One example of such a method is a hybrid model, combining parametrically constructed cluster members with a free-form large-scale mass distribution.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964911 id=\"98964911\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgements</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">GM, JR, DL, BC, VP and JM acknowledge support from the ERC starting grant 336736-CALENDS. RB, HI and FL acknowledge support from the ERC advanced grant 339659-MUSICOS. RJB gratefully acknowledges support from TOP grant TOP1.16.057 from the Nederlandse Organisatie voor Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek. LW acknowledges support by the Competitive Fund of the Leibniz Association through grant SAW-2015-AIP-2. We acknowledge fruitful discussions with Mathilde Jauzac, Keren Sharon, Jean-Paul Kneib, Eric Jullo and Marceau Limousin. This work utilizes gravitational lensing models produced by Brada\u010d, Natarajan &amp; Kneib (CATS), Merten &amp; Zitrin, Sharon, and Williams and the <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> and Diego groups. This lens modelling was partially funded by the <em>HST</em> FFs program conducted by STScI. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. The lens models were obtained from the MAST. Based on observations made with ESO Telescopes at the La Silla Paranal Observatory under programme ID 094.A-0115. Based on observations obtained with the NASA/ESA <em>HST</em>, retrieved from the MAST at the STScI. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. Also based on data obtained at the W.M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W.M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. This works makes use of <span class=\"small-caps\">mpdaf</span>, an open-source (BSD licensed) <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> package developed and maintained by CRAL and partially funded by the ERC advanced grant 339659-MUSICOS.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" data-id=\"bib79\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></span>et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2015</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">801</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">44</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/801/1/44\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F801%2F1%2F44\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F801%2F1%2F44\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964923 id=\"98964923\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: LIST OF MULTIPLE IMAGES</h3>\r\n                        <a id=\"98964924\" scrollto-destination=\"98964924\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table A1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiply imaged systems considered in this work. In the column <em>z</em><sub>ref</sub>, the letter refers to previous studies reporting spectroscopic redshifts in agreement with our detection: J for (Johnson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), R for (Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and W for (Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). M refers to this study. Column <em>conf</em> corresponds to the confidence level attached to the spectroscopic identification of the redshift. <em>emline</em> refers to emission lines detected in the spectrum and <em>absline</em> refers to absorption features. Columns rms<sub><em>x</em></sub> refer to the rms (in arcseconds) of the predicted image positions according to models runs with the related set of constraints (g for <em>gold</em>, s <em>silver</em>, b <em>bronze</em> and c <em>copper</em>). Column <em>category</em> refers to the category of confidence level in which each image belongs, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3.2</a> for a detailed description of each category.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th> ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> Dec.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>ref</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>spec</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> confi<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>model</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> absline<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> emline<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> rms<sub><em>g</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> rms<sub><em>s</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> rms<sub><em>b</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th> rms<sub><em>c</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98964924\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table A1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiply imaged systems considered in this work. In the column <em>z</em><sub>ref</sub>, the letter refers to previous studies reporting spectroscopic redshifts in agreement with our detection: J for (Johnson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), R for (Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and W for (Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). M refers to this study. Column <em>conf</em> corresponds to the confidence level attached to the spectroscopic identification of the redshift. <em>emline</em> refers to emission lines detected in the spectrum and <em>absline</em> refers to absorption features. Columns rms<sub><em>x</em></sub> refer to the rms (in arcseconds) of the predicted image positions according to models runs with the related set of constraints (g for <em>gold</em>, s <em>silver</em>, b <em>bronze</em> and c <em>copper</em>). Column <em>category</em> refers to the category of confidence level in which each image belongs, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3.2</a> for a detailed description of each category.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th> ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\"       </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964925 id=\"98964925\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX B: REDSHIFT COMPARISON WITH PREVIOUS SPECTROSCOPIC CATALOGUES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this Appendix, we compare discrepant MUSE redshift with corresponding values from the literature. The details are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a> .</p>                        <a id=\"98964927\" scrollto-destination=\"98964927\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl8\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl8\" data-id=\"tbl8\"><span class=\"label\">Table B1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the redshifts comparison with previous studies. The first subdivision use the synthesized catalogue of Boschin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and keep the original identification of object made by Couch &amp; Newell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>). The second and the third subdivisions summarize the cross-match between the MUSE redshift measurements presented in this study and the publicly available GLASS redshift catalogue (Schmidt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and the strong-lensing analysis (Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Column C refers to the confidence level associated with the MUSE redshifts, while <em>Q</em> refers to the redshift quality provided in the GLASS catalogues. Arrows (\u2192) indicate updates in redshift catalogues based on comparison.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th colspan=\"7\">Comparison of MUSE redshifts with Couch &amp; Newell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>) redshifts<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>ID<sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>C<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ID<sub>CN</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>CN</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>5693\u00a0</td><td>0.2986\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0</td><td>0.2896\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Multiple absorption features (including K, H and G) are detected in the MUSE spectra.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>9778\u00a0</td><td>0.6011\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>33\u00a0</td><td>0.4982\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>strong [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet emission is detected in the MUSE spectra.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10059\u00a0</td><td>0.3204\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>0.31\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Multiple absorption features (including K, H and G) are detected in the MUSE spectra.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10508\u00a0</td><td>0.1900\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>0.0631\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>We securely identified a very strong Detected emission in the GLASS spectra was identified as H\u03b1 by Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Discrepancy with the GLASS redshift is attributed to the lower resolution of the <em>HST</em> grisms and the source morphology convolution when extracting 1D GLASS spectra. The clear [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] detections by GLASS match the MUSE redshift.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>11419\u00a0</td><td>0.3213\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>435\u00a0</td><td>1.0500\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>The MUSE redshifts based on multiple faint absorption features and the continuum level of flux clearly identified a cluster member. Redshift disagreement unresolved.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"7\">Comparison of MUSE redshifts with Wang et\u00a0al. The first subdivision use the synthesized catalogue of Boschin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and keep the original identification of object made by Couch &amp; Newell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>). The second and the third subdivisions summarize the cross-match between the MUSE redshift measurements presented in this study and the publicly available GLASS redshift catalogue (Schmidt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and the strong-lensing analysis (Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Column C refers to the confidence level associated with the MUSE redshifts, while <em>Q</em> refers to the redshift quality provided in the GLASS catalogues. Arrows (\u2192) indicate updates in redshift catalogues based on comparison.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th colspan=\"7\">Comparison of MUSE redshifts with Couch &amp; Newell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>) redshifts<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>ID<sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). In the MUSE data cube we performed a manual extraction of image 2.1/56.1 due to the high level of contamination of the three counter images.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3402\u00a0</td><td>1.6480\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>1773\u00a0</td><td>1.660\u21921.6480\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>The MUSE redshift is based on multiple absorption feature (Al\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>, Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">a</span>nd Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>) and faint C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission. Discrepancy with the GLASS redshift is attributed to the lower resolution of the <em>HST</em> grisms and the source morphology convolution when extracting 1D GLASS spectra. The clear [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] detections by GLASS match the MUSE redshift.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>11419\u00a0</td><td>0.3213\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>435\u00a0</td><td>1.0500\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>The MUSE redshifts based on multiple faint absorption features and the continuum level of flux clearly identified a cluster member. Redshift disagreement unresolved.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"7\">Comparison of MUSE redshifts with Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) redshifts (if source is not listed in GLASS v001/v002 redshift catalogue)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ID<sub>MUSE</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>z</em><sub>MUSE</sub>\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>ID<sub>Wang\u2009et\u2009al.</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>z</em><sub>Wang\u2009et\u2009al.</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>Q</em>\u00a0</td><td>Description\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>22.2\u00a0</td><td>5.283\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>807\u00a0</td><td>4.84\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>MUSE securely identified the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission line in all multiple images of this system.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6261\u00a0</td><td>0.546\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>996\u00a0</td><td>1.14\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>The GLASS redshift was misidentified as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] instead of [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], which was realized because of a six different emission line detection in the MUSE spectrum.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7007\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>1064\u00a0</td><td>1.17\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>The H\u03b1-based redshift from the GLASS spectra is not matched by any prominent [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] or Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emission in the MUSE spectra.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98964927\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964928 id=\"98964928\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec10>APPENDIX C: IMAGE MULTIPLE</h3>\r\n                        <a id=\"98964929\" scrollto-destination=\"98964929\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figc1a\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure C1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971figc1a.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=D1V4BOPA2eVdWfb2EIIu0BHukli0SzfsDRHF3msUrTPQEuox0yb2cS1pN~rMrwJ~ssNY7iKT7~AOKydgwOcezG74gJ5NKed4pbKfEXBhrLShjFsU6O6APV676Gqg0Vs124UOonDXlqu-UinG9TjRQG41Nclbo2LTYZ71kxbI88dM1KPJ6xMXUuUPJp0b8ZBmE6LrT8QNRjEAmQsvYuVbiA3NJr6Ehx5QMsbUdYtznL8UpzYsGgP5RZJDJ5jXjR89vglelmRjzUGBMgYc7sIkY1omfWiuu~sPtoLKaJ0xQ47cKfcOYUYpnV6Hvwy6TJvbbHwG45MljtPEMBDA48aUVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Each panel presents multiply imaged systems which contains at least two images with spectroscopy. On the bottom of each panel, a spectrum presents the most obvious spectral features used to measure the redshift of the system. On top, HST RGB images made from the median-subtracted images are the 1\u03c3 contours used for the spectral extraction. Special cases are made for system 1 and 2. System 1 was detected only on the stacked spectra of the three images. Due to his large contamination by cluster members, the redshifts for system 2 was only measured based on image 2.1. Multiply-imaged systems. Image 10.2 shows an extracted region at 0.5\u03c3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971figc1a.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964929/stx1971figc1a.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971figc1a.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964929\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971figc1a.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=tp5L80JgoK5ZQGP9gwnfyE2E-ghc8Icfa1khGKsNrRJLGDimpuiTCPGIPEoIw22qaIzSnQbdIB6TvTCsG1QAUQkMDneekCbu9QZntWTcV2LX7vepKJH-DwOOlaIcOuD4lZ6NSdE2nOKWRSyyW5TUepzPWxlijjZ62KpdiObMfAlVS0o-cb1saNxXNt1KoU9C76lr7WtAMnOUWy1KxAFvnadv~E9EdHu5f6EXWmdmQRz2P4C1Yy71mK1YpGomH6L1Dyykh5DPexeaIuz77HZfAr~K~UAtgjh0TQcXuCIq~EWZg2fcb3l08umWdBeE7qZMR0eWv0T43kSmnZo8z1AYgQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964929&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971figc1a.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each panel presents multiply imaged systems which contains at least two images with spectroscopy. On the bottom of each panel, a spectrum presents the most obvious spectral features used to measure the redshift of the system. On top, <em>HST</em> RGB images made from the median-subtracted images are the 1\u03c3 contours used for the spectral extraction. Special cases are made for system 1 and 2. System 1 was detected only on the stacked spectra of the three images. Due to his large contamination by cluster members, the redshifts for system 2 was only measured based on image 2.1. Multiply-imaged systems. Image 10.2 shows an extracted region at 0.5\u03c3.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figc1a\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure C1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971figc1a.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=D1V4BOPA2eVdWfb2EIIu0BHukli0SzfsDRHF3msUrTPQEuox0yb2cS1pN~rMrwJ~ssNY7iKT7~AOKydgwOcezG74gJ5NKed4pbKfEXBhrLShjFsU6O6APV676Gqg0Vs124UOonDXlqu-UinG9TjRQG41Nclbo2LTYZ71kxbI88dM1KPJ6xMXUuUPJp0b8ZBmE6LrT8QNRjEAmQsvYuVbiA3NJr6Ehx5QMsbUdYtznL8UpzYsGgP5RZJDJ5jXjR89vglelmRjzUGBMgYc7sIkY1omfWiuu~sPtoLKaJ0xQ47cKfcOYUYpnV6Hvwy6TJvbbHwG45MljtPEMBDA48aUVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Each panel presents multiply imaged systems which contains at least two images with spectroscopy.      </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li class=\"section-jump-link head-2\" link-destination=\"98964928\">\r\n            <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div
