       <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964771 id=\"98964771\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present an analysis of Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) observations obtained on the massive Frontier Fields (FFs) cluster A2744. This new data set covers the entire multiply imaged region around the cluster core. The combined catalogue consists of 514 spectroscopic redshifts (with 414 new identifications). We use this redshift information to perform a strong-lensing analysis revising multiple images previously found in the deep FF images, and add three new MUSE-detected multiply imaged systems with no obvious <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> counterpart. The combined strong-lensing constraints include a total of 60 systems producing 188 images altogether, out of which 29 systems and 83 images are spectroscopically confirmed, making A2744 one of the most well-constrained clusters to date. Thanks to the large amount of spectroscopic redshifts, we model the influence of substructures at larger radii, using a parametrization including two cluster-scale components in the cluster core and several group scale in the outskirts. The resulting model accurately reproduces all the spectroscopic multiple systems, reaching an rms of 0.67\u2009arcsec in the image plane. The large number of MUSE spectroscopic redshifts gives us a robust model, which we estimate reduces the systematic uncertainty on the 2D mass distribution by up to \u223c2.5\u00a0times the statistical uncertainty in the cluster core. In addition, from a combination of the parametrization and the set of constraints, we estimate the relative systematic uncertainty to be up to 9\u2009per\u2009cent at 200\u2009kpc.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: imaging spectroscopy&quot;\">techniques: imaging spectroscopy</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 2744&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 2744</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964773 id=\"98964773\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster of galaxies represent a natural merging process over large scales, and as such gather many valuable observables for our Universe. From a statistical point of view, they can constraint various physical processes, such as structure formation or cosmological parameters (Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Schwinn et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). By measuring cluster mass distributions, we also gain insight into cluster-specific properties, such as dark matter content (Brada\u010d et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, Umetsu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Furthermore, offsets between the location of baryonic and dark matter profiles can be used to test the nature of dark matter (e.g. its self-interacting cross-section, Markevitch et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Harvey et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing precisely measures the enclosed mass of a cluster at a given radius, making it a powerful tool for studying dark and luminous matter. The effect occurs when the curvature of space\u2013time is large enough near the cluster centre to make different light paths from the same source converge on the field of view (FoV) of the observer.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With the first spectroscopic confirmation of a giant arc in A370 (Soucail et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>), the use of the strong-lensing effect has evolved into a valuable technique for measuring the total mass of a cluster (both luminous and non-luminous components, e.g. Limousin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). By refining the mass model of clusters, it is possible to calibrate them as cosmic telescopes and quantify the magnification of background sources to study the high-redshift Universe (Coe et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Atek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Alavi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Schmidt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The correct identification of multiply imaged background sources is crucial to lens modelling because these objects can precisely probe the mass distribution in the cluster core. This requires the high spatial resolution of the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) to ascertain their morphologies and properly match the different lensed images to the same source. By combining observations in multiple <em>HST</em> bands, Broadhurst et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) were able to identify 30 multiply imaged systems in the massive cluster A1689 based on similarities in their colours and morphologies. This idea was further pursued in the Cluster Lensing And Supernovae survey with Hubble (CLASH, Postman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Using photometry from shallow observations (\u223c1 orbit) of 25 clusters in 16 bands, Jouvel et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) finely sampled the spectral energy distribution (SED) of galaxies, obtaining accurate photometric redshifts. In the same set of data, Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) identified from 1 to 10 multiple-image systems per cluster.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">More recently, the Hubble Frontiers Field initiative (HFF, Lotz et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) combined very deep <em>HST</em> observations (\u223c180 orbits per target) of six clusters in seven bands. The HFF observed six massive clusters (typical \u223c10<sup>15</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>) at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3\u20130.6 selected for their lensing ability. In particular, their capability of strongly magnifying very distant (<em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06) galaxies. The deep images revealed a remarkable collection of hundred of multiple images in each of the six clusters observed (Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Lotz et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To tackle this wealth of data, several teams have recently engaged in an effort to accurately model the mass of the cluster cores (e.g. Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, Lam et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, Diego et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Such a large number of multiple images leads to very precise mass estimates: for example, Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) obtained &lt;1\u2009per\u2009cent statistical error on the integrated mass at 200\u2009kpc radius in the clusters MACS0416 and A2744, and Grillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) measured &lt;2\u2009per\u2009cent error on the integrated mass at 200\u2009kpc radius of MACS0416. However, the disagreement between models of the same cluster is typically (\u226510\u2009per\u2009cent), significantly larger than the statistical uncertainty (see e.g. the mass profiles presented in Lagattuta et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Therefore, the next step in further improving the accuracy of the mass estimates is to better understand the sources of systematic uncertainties. While two main drawbacks in strong-lensing analysis are the potential use of incorrectly identified multiple image systems and the lack of redshifts for the sources (used to calibrate the geometrical distance), spectroscopic confirmation of these systems is the best leverage to tackle both issues.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopic observations have greatly improved the quality of cluster mass models, as demonstrated by Limousin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), where a large spectroscopic campaign on the cluster A1689 provided redshift measurements for 24 multiple systems and enabled the rejection of incorrect multiple-image candidates in the process. However, multi-object slit spectroscopy is very costly when targeting multiple images in cluster cores due to the small number of objects (typically below 50) that can be targeted in a single observation. As demonstrated by Grillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) in CLASH clusters. Other initiatives such as the Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space (GLASS, Schmidt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) offers a valuable alternative to the slit spectroscopy by observing spectra over the entire image using a grism. The main benefit of slit-less spectroscopy is the blind search for emission in the FoV, but it is limited by low spectral resolution (typically <em>R</em>\u2009\u223c\u2009200) and strong overlap of the spectra on the detector.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A more recent alternative makes use of the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) instrument on the Very Large Telescope (VLT). MUSE is a large integral field spectrograph, providing spectra in the optical range (between 4800 and 9300 \u00c5) over its entire 1\u2009arcmin\u00d71\u2009arcmin FoV using the technology of image slicers. This provides both a large multiplexing capability and a high sensitivity, on top of a good spectral resolution (<em>R</em>\u2009\u223c\u20093000). Not only does MUSE provide an efficient follow-up of faint <em>HST</em> sources in very crowded regions, it also performs very well in the detection of very faint emission lines, especially Lyman-\u03b1 emission at high redshift (Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bina et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Drake et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Overall, these capabilities make MUSE an ideal instrument for the spectroscopic follow-up of cluster cores: its FoV is well matched with the size of the multiply imaged region and it can easily isolate line emission embedded inside the bright continuum emission of cluster members (Grillo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>; Karman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As part of the MUSE Guaranteed Time Observing (GTO) program on lensing clusters, the powerful combination of MUSE spectroscopy and the lensing efficiency of clusters is used to achieve a number of science goals: to observe the resolved properties of highly magnified distant galaxies (Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), to build reliable mass models (Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and challenge the Frontiers Fields (FFs)\u2009 modelling with dozens of images (Lagattuta et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), or to constrain the Lyman-\u03b1 luminosity function at faint luminosities (Bina et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present a MUSE-GTO spectroscopic survey and strong-lensing analysis of the HFF cluster A2744 (Couch &amp; Newell\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>; Abell, Corwin &amp; Olowin\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>, \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a000<sup>h</sup>14<sup>m</sup>19.51<sup>s</sup>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u221230\u00b023<sup>\u0384</sup>19.18<sup>\u2033</sup>, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.308). This massive (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$M(&lt;\\rm {1.3\\ Mpc})=2.3\\pm 0.1 \\ 10^{15}\\,\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>, Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), X-ray luminous (<em>L</em><sub><em>X</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a03.1\u200910<sup>45</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, Allen\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) merging cluster shows concentrated X-ray emission near its core and extending to the north-west (Owers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Eckert et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A2744 has been well studied for its complex galaxy dynamics (Owers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), and its strong-lensing properties, both through free-form (Lam et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and parametric mass modelling ( Johnson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), as well as the combination of strong and weak lensing (Merten et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a>). In their weak-lensing analysis, using both the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope and the Wide Field Imager on the MPG/European Southern Observatory (ESO) 2.2-m, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> recently identified several group-scale substructures located\u00a0\u223c\u00a0700\u2009kpc from the cluster core, each of them having masses ranging between 5 and 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Yet, despite the careful attention given to this cluster, it has suffered from a lack of spectroscopic redshifts. The most recent strong-lensing study (Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) used only seven multiply imaged sources with spectroscopic redshifts, combined with 18 photometric redshift systems, to model the mass of the cluster core.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The deepest data obtained in the MUSE GTO cluster program covered A2744 with a mosaic totaling an exposure time of 18.5\u2009h. This deep coverage makes it possible for us to obtain an incredible amount of data over the entire FoV and even confirm or reject multiply imaged systems. In addition, we supplement this data set with Low Resolution Imager and Spectrograph (LRIS) observations from Keck. Using all of this spectroscopic data, we are able to dig deeper into the nature of the cluster and advance our understanding of systematic uncertainties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we give an overview of the data. In Section 3, we describe the data processing to compute a redshift catalogue. In Section 4, we detail the strong-lensing analysis. In Section 5, we summarize the main results of the mass modelling. In Section 6, we discuss systematic uncertainties in the analysis, the influence of the outskirts and compare our results with other groups. Throughout this paper, we adopt a standard \u039b-cold dark matter cosmology with \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7 and <em>h</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.7. All magnitudes are given in the AB system (Oke\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1974</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964787 id=\"98964787\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA DESCRIPTION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964788 id=\"98964788\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Hubble Frontier Fields images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The HFF observations of A2744 (ID: 13495, PI: J. Lotz) were taken between 2013 October 25 and 2014 July 1 in seven different filters, three with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS; F435W, F606W, F814W) and four taken with the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3; F105W, F125W, F140W and F160W). In total 280 orbits were devoted to A2744 reaching in each filter a 5\u03c3 limiting magnitude AB \u223c 29. The self-calibrated data provided by Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI),<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> (version v1.0 for WFC3 and v1.0-epoch2 for ACS) with a pixel size of 60 mas are used in this study.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964790 id=\"98964790\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MUSE observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A2744 was observed with the Multi Unit Spectrographic Explorer (MUSE) between 2014 September and 2015 October as part of the GTO Program 094.A-0115 (PI: Richard). A 2\u00d72 mosaic of MUSE pointings was designed to cover the entire multiple image area, centred at \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a000<sup>h</sup>14<sup>m</sup>20.952<sup>s</sup> and \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u221230\u00b023<sup>\u0384</sup>53.88<sup>\u2033</sup>. The four quadrants were observed for a total of 3.5, 4, 4 and 5\u2009h, in addition to 2\u2009h at the centre of the cluster. Each pointing is split into 30\u2009min individual exposures with a 90\u00b0 rotation applied in between, to minimize the striping pattern caused by the IFU image slicers. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> details the MUSE exposure map overlaid on top of an HFF red giant branch (RGB) image. The full MUSE mosaic is contained within all seven HFF bands (ACS and WFC3).</p>                        <a id=\"98964792\" scrollto-destination=\"98964792\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=Cuf~UJxM1z-xF-r9MCUBe0bkyQqWNs3h48LarRN7wJCHfkDzAlZ1sVG9DokKuXiH6wX4elXygwz2eh9gGhIR61d4Jdn8HD9z5-GpDfQqRV49WU0nQOqClBp36cLQj3hUESX4G8Pdas4L~QhqxcsYDLA1UkyFo76KZuXi7eQwiA1z7k1ukyOiTmK3N6BOws8w3P0Nbq0zsRpWTdDpARBDDD~kEYydq3ywPCKQ3DfO0goDiRjDeBEkdbxXQm6ecy4VExg2fxYC6b~pGEwjp1Ih7szGzLeRHFz9WZINTqqoKmtCNHkXyIHoR4ZO5u9L5OzILDM9mt7qTnauseE8hrTCNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Full MUSE mosaic overlaid on the HFF F814W image. The shaded colour regions highlight our observing strategy, showing the total exposure time devoted to each section of the cluster. The region where multiple images are expected is marked by the white contour, and the red region shows the outline of the HFF WFC3 image mosaic.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964792/stx1971fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964792\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=wb4qShKUkz93soUPw6sW1bcy56B9KN71yp7VpUbZ9WZ3c9p6bETHEktNyDGOykveZk9E0TZ9klGRa~FGJSZCK~McCb4n23nVaoqyOINYvairpQZm825l2dgFgzA6hztsJv8N3hxDU9TKlNcuJcwIyT-fF9vvXUVK6f0pdVCR5aI7OrFcrDOigc2GbFVLhlNmPJ1FsMx4iUajnVWFmRu~sjzorlwf-HKxJqcTbRH1xKMINoO1rOcmd2IEKesdK7otetBKOXmR-P-o5dS-S8zZaFYr583w6bxb76Qf3QermyVvvIfbnVTF00BdHG7yvZFN~az~Eg28j-37-D1IKlSWag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964792&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Full MUSE mosaic overlaid on the HFF F814W image. The shaded colour regions highlight our observing strategy, showing the total exposure time devoted to each section of the cluster. The region where multiple images are expected is marked by the white contour, and the red region shows the outline of the HFF WFC3 image mosaic.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=Cuf~UJxM1z-xF-r9MCUBe0bkyQqWNs3h48LarRN7wJCHfkDzAlZ1sVG9DokKuXiH6wX4elXygwz2eh9gGhIR61d4Jdn8HD9z5-GpDfQqRV49WU0nQOqClBp36cLQj3hUESX4G8Pdas4L~QhqxcsYDLA1UkyFo76KZuXi7eQwiA1z7k1ukyOiTmK3N6BOws8w3P0Nbq0zsRpWTdDpARBDDD~kEYydq3ywPCKQ3DfO0goDiRjDeBEkdbxXQm6ecy4VExg2fxYC6b~pGEwjp1Ih7szGzLeRHFz9WZINTqqoKmtCNHkXyIHoR4ZO5u9L5OzILDM9mt7qTnauseE8hrTCNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Full MUSE mosaic overlaid on the HFF F814W image. The shaded colour regions highlight our observing strategy, showing the total exposure time devoted to each section of the cluster. The region where multiple images are expected is marked by the white contour, and the red region shows the outline of the HFF WFC3 image mosaic.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964792/stx1971fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964792\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=wb4qShKUkz93soUPw6sW1bcy56B9KN71yp7VpUbZ9WZ3c9p6bETHEktNyDGOykveZk9E0TZ9klGRa~FGJSZCK~McCb4n23nVaoqyOINYvairpQZm825l2dgFgzA6hztsJv8N3hxDU9TKlNcuJcwIyT-fF9vvXUVK6f0pdVCR5aI7OrFcrDOigc2GbFVLhlNmPJ1FsMx4iUajnVWFmRu~sjzorlwf-HKxJqcTbRH1xKMINoO1rOcmd2IEKesdK7otetBKOXmR-P-o5dS-S8zZaFYr583w6bxb76Qf3QermyVvvIfbnVTF00BdHG7yvZFN~az~Eg28j-37-D1IKlSWag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964792&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Full MUSE mosaic overlaid on the HFF F814W image. The shaded colour regions highlight our observing strategy, showing the total exposure time devoted to each section of the cluster. The region where multiple images are expected is marked by the white contour, and the red region shows the outline of the HFF WFC3 image mosaic.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964793 id=\"98964793\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3  MUSE data reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The data reduction was performed with the MUSE ESO pipeline (Weilbacher et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) up to the mosaic combination. This comprises bias subtraction, flat-fielding (including illumination and twilight exposures), sky subtraction, flux calibration and telluric correction. The last two steps were performed with calibration curves derived from the median response of six suitable standard stars observed in the MUSE GTO Lensing Clusters program. After basic corrections, we align individual exposures to a common WCS with <span class=\"small-caps\">scamp</span> (Bertin\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), shifting each frame relative to a reference image, in this case, the F814W HFF data. No correction for rotation was applied since only a maximum rotation offset of 0.03\u00b0 was observed. We then transform the realigned images into data cubes, resampling all pixels on to a common 3D grid with two spatial and one spectral axis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sky residuals were removed using the Zurich Atmosphere Purge (<span class=\"small-caps\">ZAP</span>; Soto et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), which uses principal component analysis to characterize the residuals and remove them from the cubes. Objects above a 3\u03c3 threshold, measured on an empty region on the white light of a previously combined cube, were masked during the process of residual estimation. The individual cubes were then combined in the mosaic using median absolute deviation statistics to compare exposures and reject pixels deviating by more than 3 (Gaussian-equivalent) standard deviations. To correct for variations in sky transmittance during the observations, we calculated the average fluxes of bright sources in each cube with SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>. The frame with the highest flux was then taken as a reference to scale individual exposures during combination. The final combined cube was once more cleaned with <span class=\"small-caps\">ZAP</span> and the background was corrected by subtracting the median of the 50 spectral neighbouring wavelength planes (masking bright objects) to each spatial row and column of the cube.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The final product is a 2\u2009arcmin \u00d7 2\u2009arcmin MUSE FoV mosaic with 1.25 \u00c5 spectral sampling and 0.2\u2009arcsec spatial sampling. The point spread function (PSF) size was estimated by convolving the <em>HST</em> F814W image with a moffat kernel and correlating it with a filter matched MUSE image. We obtained a moffat full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of 0.58\u2009arcsec in this filter for a \u03b2 parameter of 2.5. Comparing the fluxes of the <em>HST</em> PSF-matched image with the MUSE image, we estimate that the MUSE photometry is accurate up to \u223c7\u2009per\u2009cent. These steps were performed using the MUSE <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> Data Analysis Framework (<span class=\"small-caps\">mpdaf)</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> software. A final version of the cube is publicly available for download.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a></p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964797 id=\"98964797\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Keck/LRIS spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We observed A2744 using the LRIS on the Keck-I telescope, during the night of 2015 December 7. One single spectroscopic mask covered seven multiple images selected in the cluster core: 1.1, 10.3, 25.3, 35.1, 37.1, 39.1 and 57.2 over 4.8 and 4.5 ks in the blue and red arms of the instrument, respectively. The blue arm was equipped with the 400 lines mm<sup>\u22121</sup> grism blazed at 3400 \u00c5, while the red arm was equipped with the 400 lines mm<sup>\u22121</sup> grism blazed at 8500 \u00c5. The light for both arms was separated using the 6800 \u00c5 dichroic.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This configuration provided nearly complete coverage of the wavelength range 3500\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u03bb\u00a0&lt;\u00a09700 \u00c5, with a spectral resolution of 5.2 and 4.8 \u00c5 in the blue and red arms, respectively. Each slit was individually reduced using standard <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> procedures for bias subtraction, flat-fielding, wavelength and flux calibration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We inspected each 2D reduced slit for faint emission lines and identify clear emission in the spectrum of images 35.1 and 37.1, centred at 4446 and 4438 \u00c5, respectively. The absence of any other strong emission line in the wavelength range gives a secure identification of Lyman \u03b1 at similar redshifts: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.656 for image 35.1 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.650 for image 37.1. No strong spectral feature was found in any the other multiple images included in the mask.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964801 id=\"98964801\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 DATA ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since MUSE is most sensitive to emission line objects, very faint (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub> \u226525) sources lacking emission lines can be hard to detect. Therefore, in order to extract the maximum number of sources possible, we applied three complementary detection methods over the entire field: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Forced spectral extraction at the location of known faint sources detected in deep (m<sub>lim</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a030) HFF imaging.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Emission line detection of sources based on a narrow-band filtering of the MUSE cube mosaic.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A few manual extractions of sources not captured by (i) and (ii) and found through visual inspection of the data cube (see, e.g. the special case of multiply imaged system 2 explained in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>).</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then searched the combined list of objects extracted with methods (i)\u2013(iii) for spectral features, measuring redshifts which we compared to ancillary redshift catalogues of A2744. This process is described in the following subsections.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964804 id=\"98964804\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 <em>HST</em> photometric catalogue</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our MUSE spectral extraction (method (i) described above) relies on apertures defined using a photometric catalogue. We build this catalogue taking full advantage of the depth and high spatial resolution of the HFF images to detect as many objects as possible. However, diffuse intracluster light (ICL) is an important and significant component of the core of the clusters and affects the detection of faint sources in the vicinity of cluster members, which is usually the case for multiple images (e.g. Montes &amp; Trujillo\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Livermore, Finkelstein &amp; Lotz\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Merlin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). For this study, we remove the ICL and cluster member wings in each filter by subtracting the results of a running median, calculated within a window of \u223c1.3\u2009arcsec (21\u2009pixels with 60 mas pixel scale <em>HST</em> images). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> illustrates the improvement of our filtering procedure on the extraction of faint objects in a heavily crowded region near the cluster core. The ICL-subtracted images were weighted by their inverse-variance map and combined into one deep image. To perform a consistent photometric analysis <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) was used in dual-image mode, with objects detected in the combined image and their fluxes measured from the individual median-subtracted images.</p>                        <a id=\"98964806\" scrollto-destination=\"98964806\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=XlC3sre2Dv0XZCEVUxCD8iUGUX2Cy0X-zMs-5NQfvJxviYjZVHLmTJIwwYb7cxHKfyX1FKMLrl6leWdH-X7kvA-PTpu5~vvSny-4F2b0SC-FPm7Lvq4kMoyqRlpXtT3g9wx2b1spQuwFVFnDxryrlniUtBbSURx8scDuF7pqXXzq9UBEYfo~B-fhEiMSE3iIsgiZKSeo0TLHk9GXg2Zjgnne2EQW-i910fk6JtjsHQ-vXwDt45HUeRGq3xhQ2hnBtlNb4fCruunlKoqg0gjghQ4-hn0wbwUeHVtg2jflnEXtzEXeJds77oJRkpfhJ5G7RHWn9ZYQQdx-Dwj8Z11uGg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example of the procedure used to subtract the ICL. Each panel is 23\u2009arcsec (105\u2009kpc at z = 0.308) on a side. The white rectangles in the inserted panels show the location of the zoomed area. On the left, a region in the original HST F814W filter. On the right, the same region and filter with the median removed, as described in Section\u00a03.1. The scale and colour levels used in the two panels are the same. The median filter is calculated in a 21\u00a0\u00d7\u00a021\u2009pixel running window. The ICL and wings of bright cluster members are largely removed, leading to an increased contrast around small and faint sources, improving their detectability. The green contours show segmentation maps from identical detection set-ups.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964806/stx1971fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964806\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=Iwq10zMGL1ZZzOgj11ED1hPEwoj2SPO08-kHSVH2Tq3MSBFkiw3zU8b8Oii5OSKPopliNZ~KuOS128e6yqLn--n8INk-L~6SVxiauIeorYjt0lRx5fLqJAbpKp0A6MVdi4fBT~vWuwe~tCZXvXtUD4rXSI1-YJTGglw0Z0C7H5nTUajmcFTahJa98h0Ld~UExciWPdAJPdUS3fB7x3Q--5JmNbAncsbxz0z5~bzymCVjv6a~HEZf8jeYG2nkJ9Yrk1-y~w8r~K8XwjZgu3j6lsILl6NvasibCVAtTge9cL6KMaiiDC0xC5oXsDuo9bwjfQF6u3iZrlS5P1ORjPvcVg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964806&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of the procedure used to subtract the ICL. Each panel is 23\u2009arcsec (105\u2009kpc at <em>z</em> = 0.308) on a side. The white rectangles in the inserted panels show the location of the zoomed area. On the left, a region in the original <em>HST</em> F814W filter. On the right, the same region and filter with the median removed, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1</a>. The scale and colour levels used in the two panels are the same. The median filter is calculated in a 21\u00a0\u00d7\u00a021\u2009pixel running window. The ICL and wings of bright cluster members are largely removed, leading to an increased contrast around small and faint sources, improving their detectability. The green contours show segmentation maps from identical detection set-ups.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=XlC3sre2Dv0XZCEVUxCD8iUGUX2Cy0X-zMs-5NQfvJxviYjZVHLmTJIwwYb7cxHKfyX1FKMLrl6leWdH-X7kvA-PTpu5~vvSny-4F2b0SC-FPm7Lvq4kMoyqRlpXtT3g9wx2b1spQuwFVFnDxryrlniUtBbSURx8scDuF7pqXXzq9UBEYfo~B-fhEiMSE3iIsgiZKSeo0TLHk9GXg2Zjgnne2EQW-i910fk6JtjsHQ-vXwDt45HUeRGq3xhQ2hnBtlNb4fCruunlKoqg0gjghQ4-hn0wbwUeHVtg2jflnEXtzEXeJds77oJRkpfhJ5G7RHWn9ZYQQdx-Dwj8Z11uGg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example of the procedure used to subtract the ICL. Each panel is 23\u2009arcsec (105\u2009kpc at z = 0.308) on a side. The white rectangles in the inserted panels show the location of the zoomed area. On the left, a region in the original HST F814W filter. On the right, the same region and filter with the median removed, as described in Section\u00a03.1. The scale and colour levels used in the two panels are the same. The median filter is calculated in a 21\u00a0\u00d7\u00a021\u2009pixel running window. The ICL and wings of bright cluster members are largely removed, leading to an increased contrast around small and faint sources, improving their detectability. The green contours show segmentation maps from identical detection set-ups.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964806/stx1971fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964806\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=Iwq10zMGL1ZZzOgj11ED1hPEwoj2SPO08-kHSVH2Tq3MSBFkiw3zU8b8Oii5OSKPopliNZ~KuOS128e6yqLn--n8INk-L~6SVxiauIeorYjt0lRx5fLqJAbpKp0A6MVdi4fBT~vWuwe~tCZXvXtUD4rXSI1-YJTGglw0Z0C7H5nTUajmcFTahJa98h0Ld~UExciWPdAJPdUS3fB7x3Q--5JmNbAncsbxz0z5~bzymCVjv6a~HEZf8jeYG2nkJ9Yrk1-y~w8r~K8XwjZgu3j6lsILl6NvasibCVAtTge9cL6KMaiiDC0xC5oXsDuo9bwjfQF6u3iZrlS5P1ORjPvcVg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964806&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of the procedure used to subtract the ICL. Each panel is 23\u2009arcsec (105\u2009kpc at <em>z</em> = 0.308) on a side. The white rectangles in the inserted panels show the location of the zoomed area. On the left, a region in the original <em>HST</em> F814W filter. On the right, the same region and filter with the median removed, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1</a>. The scale and colour levels used in the two panels are the same. The median filter is calculated in a 21\u00a0\u00d7\u00a021\u2009pixel running window. The ICL and wings of bright cluster members are largely removed, leading to an increased contrast around small and faint sources, improving their detectability. The green contours show segmentation maps from identical detection set-ups.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">By using the median-subtraction process, we inevitably underestimate the total flux of individual galaxies. To measure the level of underestimation, we compare photometric data between images with and without median subtraction. For consistency, we use identical detection set-ups on both images. We find that the total flux is underestimated by about 50\u2009per\u2009cent for bright objects (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub> \u223c 20) and by \u223c15\u2009per\u2009cent for faint objects (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub> \u223c 27). However, the contrast and detectability of faint and peaky objects is also increased by \u223c15\u2009per\u2009cent. The <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> parameters used to construct this catalogue are provided for reference in the published catalogue.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964808 id=\"98964808\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Extracting spectra</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The resolution and sensitivity of the HFF images give morphological information of continuum emission, enabling us to deblend close pairs of objects. Based on the deblended source catalogue, an associated extraction area was used to extract spectral information from the MUSE data cube according to the largest PSF measured (\u223c0.7\u2009arcsec), which appeared to be on the bluest part of the cube. The extraction area is based on a SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> segmentation map of each individual object broadened by a Gaussian convolution with an FWHM matched to this PSF. The resulting mask is rebinned to match the MUSE spatial sampling (0.2\u2009arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) and the area of the mask is cut-off at 10\u2009per\u2009cent of the maximum flux. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> highlights steps of the masking process. MUSE pixels within the mask are combined in each wavelength plane, weighting each pixel by the signal-to-noise ratio. For further details of the method see Horne (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>). We note that our chosen set of detection parameters led SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> to deblend the most extended sources, such as giant arcs, into multiple objects in the catalogue. In these few cases, spectra were extracted after visual inspection and manual merging of the segmentation regions.</p>                        <a id=\"98964810\" scrollto-destination=\"98964810\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=RoAsbiybND9RmHjpWb~pmGcc7TVa8cFkJcgAcubTA~VqISEYz0rovIwXkJEaWj8aGEtDh3qLURXaqMP4KmaKH94RsibDar3rmqQ66TcfXkIPEmBdlyMfx9SfHULSUoJ8sBgohjTMxOGRTjZRVJRR9fi2r3cMjBtJSmNfaNvWlg2Jn9vGsnaNhmSHoWqHGR7BjR3SHzZXXirWNUaCjCgav9Yr6Y3v90z1gsQzOS8JlOUKh3axHzHFT95peTFhN0-8fvY3yWFm4IJJ7IGCBQ82-RyNVt08~hbryMrs4RrjMpZLK4rZO~d4lH6srsIyGfEOkmnsv0Qw-HmvDBa6PtHSkQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"From left to right: (1) combined HST image used for source detection in the photometric catalogue. The magenta contour represents the HST-based detection, while the orange contour represents the 10\u2009per\u2009cent cut-off level of normalized flux, after convolving the segmentation map to the MUSE seeing. Each panel is \u223c6.25\u2009arcsec on a side.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964810/stx1971fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964810\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=LNFG8K25FwUcAr8n-VlsuLyz9MEwHIS6yChNE8M8Mhq8jH3WmcnmzY2Bdp1IOM9kANqa3kxpGvERHZcR-rINUGaRQkE4EQkrxN54CT45uLPmI1TjYxK3ENFCBirSaNsRMeXhbheoREgc2G9WIjx-cdm23HHd11-ItdITUEMOlAcCyLM1SGEQzaNks-sL-4yYmsO7JiBXnhRvvsEY0yrGrCG0CKBoGLm~aW9s4bj2MdSZyNy7xQBhoEe5pykJKrQo-CnnNu1U5yxSdRAUPGohJwHuHUvJWRhtVWLEZPos7uqNwrCLkNFb4fT9jxjlr3fpoSUrFdYCbYx8We6ICFHaGQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964810&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From left to right: (1) combined <em>HST</em> image used for source detection in the photometric catalogue. Each panel is \u223c6.25\u2009arcsec on a side.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=RoAsbiybND9RmHjpWb~pmGcc7TVa8cFkJcgAcubTA~VqISEYz0rovIwXkJEaWj8aGEtDh3qLURXaqMP4KmaKH94RsibDar3rmqQ66TcfXkIPEmBdlyMfx9SfHULSUoJ8sBgohjTMxOGRTjZRVJRR9fi2r3cMjBtJSmNfaNvWlg2Jn9vGsnaNhmSHoWqHGR7BjR3SHzZXXirWNUaCjCgav9Yr6Y3v90z1gsQzOS8JlOUKh3axHzHFT95peTFhN0-8fvY3yWFm4IJJ7IGCBQ82-RyNVt08~hbryMrs4RrjMpZLK4rZO~d4lH6srsIyGfEOkmnsv0Qw-HmvDBa6PtHSkQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"From left to right: (1) combined HST image used for source detection in the photometric catalogue. Each panel is \u223c6.25\u2009arcsec on a side.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964810/stx1971fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964810\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=LNFG8K25FwUcAr8n-VlsuLyz9MEwHIS6yChNE8M8Mhq8jH3WmcnmzY2Bdp1IOM9kANqa3kxpGvERHZcR-rINUGaRQkE4EQkrxN54CT45uLPmI1TjYxK3ENFCBirSaNsRMeXhbheoREgc2G9WIjx-cdm23HHd11-ItdITUEMOlAcCyLM1SGEQzaNks-sL-4yYmsO7JiBXnhRvvsEY0yrGrCG0CKBoGLm~aW9s4bj2MdSZyNy7xQBhoEe5pykJKrQo-CnnNu1U5yxSdRAUPGohJwHuHUvJWRhtVWLEZPos7uqNwrCLkNFb4fT9jxjlr3fpoSUrFdYCbYx8We6ICFHaGQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964810&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From left to right: (1) combined <em>HST</em> image used for source detection in the photometric catalogue. (2) Associated SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> segmentation map, convolved to the MUSE seeing level. (3) MUSE data, collapsed over all wavelengths. The magenta contour represents the <em>HST</em>-based detection, while the orange contour represents the 10\u2009per\u2009cent cut-off level of normalized flux, after convolving the segmentation map to the MUSE seeing. Each panel is \u223c6.25\u2009arcsec on a side.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964811 id=\"98964811\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Automatic line detection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Complementing the extraction method based on <em>HST</em> continuum levels, we search the MUSE data cube for emission lines using the dedicated software <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> This analysis tool produces a large number of pseudo-narrow-band images over the entire wavelength range of the MUSE cube, summing the flux over five wavelength bins (6.25 \u00c5) and subtracting the corresponding median-filtered continuum estimated over two cube slices of 25 \u00c5 width each.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> is then used on each of these narrow-band images to detect the flux excess due to emission lines. All SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> catalogues are then matched and merged to produce a list of line emissions which may or may not be associated with strong continuum flux. When multiple emission lines are identified for a single source, the redshift is automatically provided, otherwise the remaining lines are visually inspected to identify [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]<sub>\u03bb\u2009\u03bb\u20093727,\u20093729</sub>, Ly\u03b1 or another line.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964814 id=\"98964814\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Catalogue construction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift assessment was performed independently by six authors (GM, JR, BC, DL, VP and JM), using several methods. We systematically reviewed all <em>HST</em>-based extracted sources down to a signal-to-noise ratio in the continuum where no secure redshift relying on continuum or absorption features were able to be assessed. This empirically corresponds to an <em>HST</em> magnitude of <em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub>\u00a0=\u00a024.4. Each of these spectra was at least reviewed by one of the authors. The redshift catalogue was completed with information from the emission line finder <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> where reviewers also checked every line suggested by the software. Multiply imaged systems already recorded throughout the literature (Johnson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Lam et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Kawamata et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) were carefully vetted by the same six authors in order to increase confidence in the redshift assessment. We assigned each measured redshift a confidence level based on the strength of spectral features according to the following rules: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Confidence 3: secure redshift, with several strong spectral features.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Confidence 2: probable redshift, relying on 1 spectral feature or several faint absorption features.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Confidence 1: tentative redshift.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of spectra assigned confidence 1, 2 and 3 are shown in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98964817\" scrollto-destination=\"98964817\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=Oc-qVR7Wvv-p3Qt1ddtigy0PFbMVdEKDt2IlG~O~uaiZhm90e3LAPDA95IDWPW12-wn1uKTYE2oPNuAPW2gijZWFk7PKQS-PUeQ7CWt5BLzkapIaEKwITFqXE37PkBLwW~L-DR4ByEwa-kh1kjklKN8RAYG7JqP9GtYF3ahpFr7NGa30ANj21w7eoA7ml3LPP66PlB-HxCXUN6UZNhGWQTl7y73U740It1BRg49RK-jEQ6gU6fZ3NWYjgm~-WJK3zE6vFLUmlwppSQjFwiyhMAwcVEZ9PcqXFOAmzZt1tNI3j-1KHGvGUl7DXRshpcadnk3iGgPej9NlsE~oM7dYeQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of 1D spectral identification. The four rows highlight the grading process in terms of confidence level. Panels on the left show the complete spectrum, while panels on the right show the zoomed-in region marked by the grey-shaded area. Spectra are graded into three levels of confidence, from 1 (tentative), to 3 (secure). See Section\u00a03.4 for details. From top to bottom, we show: a confidence 3 spectrum identified by multiple emission line features (marked by the vertical dashed lines), a confidence 3 spectrum based on absorption features, a confidence 2 spectrum based on a single line detection and a confidence 1 spectrum with a tentative, faint emission line feature identified as [O\u2009ii].\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964817/stx1971fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=NZZwXeCc~FgRQEdZBA9H~ASFkM-1PZb5o1O~yPLItv7vSzKHpX3QZ5Gp9JPbIIN6U5k~bDNqz08sW1uPWmdaT4HWVA1N9J6R6hsArCxEHXhY4T9bTjjZ8KsFAVbPRse05oNN7mnnQ5jK5kbz-giYZ7I0LwAWUez8uq3~sfDqYEVMsQLMaAjVsVvd3dIrtlhVCQdUudTwcPFiwQEbNd8VdnJRI7E1LK0sepieLmD8rT168MwV8uRiTQvcnyNUxwf11NwT1X4i0gKAB9REyXd9NfezdUun-Mfnq6i9GA7Hgx8tUTSotizfh3G2UQc9lXl0Gvj4CUpVauLGj40Y9dnSNA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964817&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of 1D spectral identification. The four rows highlight the grading process in terms of confidence level. Panels on the left show the complete spectrum, while panels on the right show the zoomed-in region marked by the grey-shaded area. Spectra are graded into three levels of confidence, from 1 (tentative), to 3 (secure). See Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.4</a> for details. From top to bottom, we show: a confidence 3 spectrum identified by multiple emission line features (marked by the vertical dashed lines), a confidence 3 spectrum based on absorption features, a confidence 2 spectrum based on a single line detection and a confidence 1 spectrum with a tentative, faint emission line feature identified as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>].</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=Oc-qVR7Wvv-p3Qt1ddtigy0PFbMVdEKDt2IlG~O~uaiZhm90e3LAPDA95IDWPW12-wn1uKTYE2oPNuAPW2gijZWFk7PKQS-PUeQ7CWt5BLzkapIaEKwITFqXE37PkBLwW~L-DR4ByEwa-kh1kjklKN8RAYG7JqP9GtYF3ahpFr7NGa30ANj21w7eoA7ml3LPP66PlB-HxCXUN6UZNhGWQTl7y73U740It1BRg49RK-jEQ6gU6fZ3NWYjgm~-WJK3zE6vFLUmlwppSQjFwiyhMAwcVEZ9PcqXFOAmzZt1tNI3j-1KHGvGUl7DXRshpcadnk3iGgPej9NlsE~oM7dYeQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of 1D spectral identification. The four rows highlight the grading process in terms of confidence level. Panels on the left show the complete spectrum, while panels on the right show the zoomed-in region marked by the grey-shaded area. Spectra are graded into three levels of confidence, from 1 (tentative), to 3 (secure). See Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.4</a> for details. From top to bottom, we show: a confidence 3 spectrum identified by multiple emission line features (marked by the vertical dashed lines), a confidence 3 spectrum based on absorption features, a confidence 2 spectrum based on a single line detection and a confidence 1 spectrum with a tentative, faint emission line feature identified as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>].</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We next construct a master redshift catalogue, including only spectra with a confidence level of 2 or 3. The only exceptions are made for multiply imaged systems ranked as very secure photometric candidates by HFF lens modellers (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> for more details). The master redshift catalogue was compared to entries in the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://ned.ipac.caltech.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://ned.ipac.caltech.edu</a>), the publicly available redshift catalogue from the GLASS collaboration<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> and the redshifts presented by Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and corrected as needed. The details of this comparison is presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The final catalogue contains 514 redshifts, including 10 with confidence 1 and 133 with confidence 2 and 371 with confidence 3. The spectral and spatial distributions of this catalogue can be seen in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> presents the very first entries of the catalogue and the full version is available in the online version.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a></p>                        <a id=\"98964820\" scrollto-destination=\"98964820\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=i5AQu5MyMP-fVDVYd-86rPkDJr0zHqFl4yOFDZXO2R-vUx9YGXf4s8mJeaHNM1yIiEQsxS6lW-3k2s3R38zMwQn8H9tPqVYzbrl1Zq64EIndSJ2Kx-NTozGrhyAsrQzCGYTZJxC9ZrN-kGLGdWoUIjWHnetO5CmA7AFr7KhT0k-ROk4dv5VMhy3yYdO0rjBLKVqEbLT-0pvuHZmOYwmAxTu0eFNa8RIDuD-vdtZ~YRhrmeMaT6bCg0nbKrYIYClnJGgKRsjpRhEculAKkQxK-UJ5UrYnaNZ7HxE9w2joAlMfcfzS1w2y03xpizfJk23mDA859KoXX0rkfDzG9X4ZKg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The top panel represents the spatial distribution of all secure redshifts, superimposed on an RGB HST image. The dark blue box represents the full extent of the 2\u2009arcmin \u00d7\u20092\u2009arcmin MUSE mosaic, while the white line encloses the multiple image area for objects with z \u2264 10. The lower panels represent the redshift histogram of the same sources. The darker colour represents confidence 3 objects and the lighter colour represents confidence 2 objects. The lower left panel presents the foreground redshifts with respect to the cluster. The lower middle panel shows the cluster redshifts distribution. The lower right panel shows the redshift distribution of background sources. The black dashed line shows the number of independent background sources (corrected from the multiplicity due to lensing). The dark blue box represents the full extent of the 2\u2009arcmin \u00d7\u20092\u2009arcmin MUSE mosaic, while the white line encloses the multiple image area for objects with <em>z</em> \u2264 10. The lower panels represent the redshift histogram of the same sources. The darker colour represents confidence 3 objects and the lighter colour represents confidence 2 objects. The lower left panel presents the foreground redshifts with respect to the cluster. The lower middle panel shows the cluster redshifts distribution. The lower right panel shows the redshift distribution of background sources. The black dashed line shows the number of independent background sources (corrected from the multiplicity due to lensing). Note that the bin sizes differ in the three bottom panels (\u0394<em>z\u2009</em>\u2009\u2248\u20090.0165, 0.001 and 0.119, respectively)</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"98964821\" scrollto-destination=\"98964821\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">First six lines of the redshift catalogue released with this work. The columns ID, RA, Dec. and <em>z</em> represent the identification number, the right ascension, the declination and the redshift of each entry. The column CONFID represents the confidence level of the detection, from 3 for very secure down to 1 for less secure identifications according to our grading policy, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.4</a>. TYPE represents the classification of the object based on the system used for the MUSE-UDF analysis (Bacon et\u00a0al.\u2009in preparation): TYPE=0 are stars, TYPE=2 are [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters, TYPE=3 are absorption line galaxies, TYPE=4 are C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii]</span> emitters and TYPE=6 are Lyman-\u03b1 emitters (the other MUSE-UDF TYPE do not match any entries of this catalogue). The MUL column shows the multiple image ID if it is reported in our strong-lensing analysis. Columns named FXXXW and FXXXW_ERR present the photometry and its error in the seven <em>HST</em> filters used in this study. MU and MU_ERR represent the magnification ratio and its error computed from our lensing mass model. Objects MXX are only detected in the MUSE cube as they do not match any entry from our photometric catalogue.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98964821\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">First six lines of the redshift catalogue released with this work. The columns ID, RA, Dec. and <em>z</em> represent the identification number, the right ascension, the declination and the redshift of each entry. The column CONFID represents the confidence level of the detection, from 3 for very secure down to 1 for less secure identifications according to our grading policy, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.4</a>. TYPE represents the classification of the object based on the system used for the MUSE-UDF analysis (Bacon et\u00a0al.\u2009in preparation): TYPE=0 are stars, TYPE=2 are [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters, TYPE=3 are absorption line galaxies, TYPE=4 are C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii]</span> emitters and TYPE=6 are Lyman-\u03b1 emitters (the other MUSE-UDF TYPE do not match any entries of this catalogue). The MUL column shows the multiple image ID if it is reported in our strong-lensing analysis. Columns named FXXXW and FXXXW_ERR present the photometry and its error in the seven <em>HST</em> filters used in this study. MU and MU_ERR represent the magnification ratio and its error computed from our lensing mass model. Objects MXX are only detected in the MUSE cube as they do not match any entry from our photometric catalogue.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span
