no-formula-id\">|$^{+4.3}_{-8.3}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[13.2]\u00a0</td><td>[0.1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>SouthGal\u00a0</td><td>[\u221212.7]\u00a0</td><td>[\u22120.8]\u00a0</td><td>[0.3]\u00a0</td><td>[\u221246.6]\u00a0</td><td>186.6<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+7.6}_{-8.5}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>0.4<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.9}_{-0.8}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[0.1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>L</em>* Galaxy\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>166.0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+1.0}_{-2.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>12.8<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.2}_{-0.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> clumps A\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>196.3<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+1.8}_{-1.7}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[300.0]\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> clumps B\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>75.5<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+9.8}_{-5.1}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98964868\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Looking into the <em>bronze</em>-constrained model, we can see the rms has increased relative to the <em>silver</em>-constrained model, returning to the same level as the original <em>gold</em>-constrained model. However, the penalty of adding the additional constraints is clearly seen since the BIC is significantly larger than either the <em>gold</em>- or <em>silver</em>-constrained model values.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The considerably larger rms value for the model with <em>copper</em> constraints is mainly due to systematics, such as including the wrong (non-spectroscopic) counter image to systems which have spectroscopic redshifts. This may include images 10.3 and 37.3, which provide some of the largest rms errors on the model (rms<sub>37.3</sub> = 9.62\u2009arcsec; rms<sub>10.3</sub> = 4.91\u2009arcsec), see the rms columns in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98964871 id=\"98964871\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We discuss here the overall structure of the cluster A2744 in the context of the new MUSE data. We investigate the dynamics of cluster members and the influence of the environment of the cluster on our models.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964873 id=\"98964873\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Dynamics of the cluster core</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) performed the largest spectroscopic survey of cluster members to date in the A2744 field, using the AAOmega spectrograph on the Anglo-Australian Telescope. They measured redshifts for 343 members within a 3\u2009Mpc projected radius from the cluster core. Their analysis of the cluster dynamics clearly preferred a model including three dynamical components, with two distinct clumps (A and B) centred around the cluster core and a separate LOS velocity distribution encompassing the rest of the cluster. The strong-lensing region we model in this paper is referred to as the southern compact core in their study.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Despite covering a smaller region around this core (<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0550\u2009kpc), we measure redshifts for 156 cluster members using the new MUSE observations (Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, middle panel). To get a more robust estimate of their relative velocities, we refine these redshifts using the <span class=\"small-caps\">auto-z</span> (Baldry et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) software, cross-correlating each spectrum with template spectra consisting of both passive and star-forming galaxies. In Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, we present a 2D map of the LOS velocities relative to the cluster redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3064, defined as the mean redshift in Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The colour scheme used in the figure reflects the relative velocity of each cluster member, while the symbol size is scaled according to the brightness in the ACS/F814W band from our photometric catalogue.</p>                        <a id=\"98964876\" scrollto-destination=\"98964876\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=tzVR598PZOPSJ9kfbeUzHNLGMAhk~IKvlr2G~KYR4rQToJ0lkGH7IUXl5PEFm1SN5CEhplIrmyRHn5JtemTWe-l0IeU4a-vPCkY~IlvRpq9pWsa3DrfkGVPDHlbcfnFzr22IsXUMtdz~TroeEDNA6Nwbe-KXvqPrzPgxRrsPx4qNSS8megteLCC0FzmF1UPfuEfmJjWBpNiqD9lAA~MWB32p0H4xr31nnZIYn8UWUI0WFZRix5YPBhNgzXnRX8oC0btG3xelvjjpQKGB6x9LSF53wdiuzVPham7K5W-s1ZSUB8SABLPz47HmAtdUz1nQ0eHMn532losdZYdpYNlNmQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spatial map of the velocity shift of cluster members, relative to the systemic cluster velocity. Circle symbols represent galaxies with no emission lines and star symbols represent galaxies with strong emission lines. The histogram of velocities is shown in the inset, overplotted with the velocity peaks found in Owers et\u00a0al. (2011) and our study. For reference, we also show mass contours of the cluster (blue lines) at 1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0109, 1.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0109 and 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0109 M\u2299\u2009kpc\u22122.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964876/stx1971fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964876\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=SvDzrZk8PNlJ88P8-YUEVASIig0mh9HHfMSMJ8Tl4~FD9oU~r6UUQ7Sb2QUYjotBr7w7LAzGVUDMTVGIDzEK857WVYokWe8bY-Xqu7uyOfVZYMW2wChh0CD2hDrGdV~ITvv-JxHZmjpcGQyR82dp3vg3zDiLFw-ZFxXyWtkmTv0~c99PpLr5~iCWObWdFE9TebJXXA50OsVoSObi6CjMvp8lTvnZ50CLmdCI8XtDfaQhdfACTKEWhdl1xpVKUYNd4MH2WpBgwo8OHU8co12NqQ3IVK0sYQA3NK2eFYu~T-VnLmf2uyAWbNTUk8oFRVczXSqaJ7a8jGnuUNYLod1ruw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964876&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spatial map of the velocity shift of cluster members, relative to the systemic cluster velocity. Circle symbols represent galaxies with no emission lines and star symbols represent galaxies with strong emission lines. The histogram of velocities is shown in the inset, overplotted with the velocity peaks found in Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and our study. For reference, we also show mass contours of the cluster (blue lines) at 1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup>, 1.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup> and 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=tzVR598PZOPSJ9kfbeUzHNLGMAhk~IKvlr2G~KYR4rQToJ0lkGH7IUXl5PEFm1SN5CEhplIrmyRHn5JtemTWe-l0IeU4a-vPCkY~IlvRpq9pWsa3DrfkGVPDHlbcfnFzr22IsXUMtdz~TroeEDNA6Nwbe-KXvqPrzPgxRrsPx4qNSS8megteLCC0FzmF1UPfuEfmJjWBpNiqD9lAA~MWB32p0H4xr31nnZIYn8UWUI0WFZRix5YPBhNgzXnRX8oC0btG3xelvjjpQKGB6x9LSF53wdiuzVPham7K5W-s1ZSUB8SABLPz47HmAtdUz1nQ0eHMn532losdZYdpYNlNmQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spatial map of the velocity shift of cluster members, relative to the systemic cluster velocity. Circle symbols represent galaxies with no emission lines and star symbols represent galaxies with strong emission lines. The histogram of velocities is shown in the inset, overplotted with the velocity peaks found in Owers et\u00a0al. (2011) and our study. For reference, we also show mass contours of the cluster (blue lines) at 1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0109, 1.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0109 and 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0109 M\u2299\u2009kpc\u22122.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964876/stx1971fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964876\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=SvDzrZk8PNlJ88P8-YUEVASIig0mh9HHfMSMJ8Tl4~FD9oU~r6UUQ7Sb2QUYjotBr7w7LAzGVUDMTVGIDzEK857WVYokWe8bY-Xqu7uyOfVZYMW2wChh0CD2hDrGdV~ITvv-JxHZmjpcGQyR82dp3vg3zDiLFw-ZFxXyWtkmTv0~c99PpLr5~iCWObWdFE9TebJXXA50OsVoSObi6CjMvp8lTvnZ50CLmdCI8XtDfaQhdfACTKEWhdl1xpVKUYNd4MH2WpBgwo8OHU8co12NqQ3IVK0sYQA3NK2eFYu~T-VnLmf2uyAWbNTUk8oFRVczXSqaJ7a8jGnuUNYLod1ruw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964876&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spatial map of the velocity shift of cluster members, relative to the systemic cluster velocity. Circle symbols represent galaxies with no emission lines and star symbols represent galaxies with strong emission lines. The histogram of velocities is shown in the inset, overplotted with the velocity peaks found in Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and our study. For reference, we also show mass contours of the cluster (blue lines) at 1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup>, 1.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup> and 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> reveals a clear dichotomy in the distribution of velocities, with two groups of cluster members at low and high velocities centred around the NW and SE regions, respectively. Star-forming cluster members (represented by star symbols in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> and selected from [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission) tend to be located in the outskirts of the FoV (&gt;100\u2009kpc radius), where the surface mass density of the cluster drops below 1.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The bimodality in the distribution of velocities appears clearly in the redshift histogram (Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, inset). We adjust each of the two components (separated at <em>v</em>\u00a0=\u00a0870\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>) with a Gaussian distribution and find the parameters (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v_{\\rm \\text{centre}}=-1308\\pm 161$|</span> km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a01277\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0189\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>) and (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v_{\\rm \\text{centre}}=2644\\pm 72$|</span> km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0695\u00a0\u00b1\u00a076\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>). These values are remarkably close to the parameters found by Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) for clump B (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v_{\\rm \\text{centre}}=-1658$|</span> km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0789\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>) and clump A (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v_{\\rm \\text{centre}}=2574$|</span> km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0441\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>), respectively, as seen in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. The main difference is a small excess in the distribution of galaxies in the velocity range [\u2212200, 800] km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This excess could be due to the presence of cluster members that do not belong to the A or B clump.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to the clear gap in velocities between the two clumps A and B (\u223c4000\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>), the simplest hypothesis would suggest a pre-merger phase between those two components (e.g. Maurogordato et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). These clumps are separated by\u00a0\u223c\u00a075\u2009kpc in projection, along a similar SE\u2013NW direction as the two DM mass clumps of the mass model. This projected distance is small but significant: the two clumps are therefore separated both spatially and dynamically. This small offset strengthens the assumption of a merging process along the LOS. However, the relative complexity of the X-ray emission in the cluster (Owers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) suggest a more complicated scenario. A joint analysis of the temperature of the gas and the dynamics of galaxies would shed light into the cluster merging history, but is out of the scope of the paper.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964880 id=\"98964880\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 External shear effect</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we discuss the relevance of including external shear in the model, first mentioned in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a>. To probe for shear effects, we build three models using only the <em>gold</em> spectroscopic constraints. The first model, called the \u2018reference\u2019 model, is built according to the methodology reported in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>, only including mass potentials which are in the WFC3 FoV. After optimizing this model, we find a best-fitting rms of 0.86\u2009arcsec. Next, we add a constant external shear field to the reference model which reduces the global rms (0.78\u2009arcsec) during optimization. This model is known as the \u2018external shear\u2019 model. Finally, we replace the external shear field with the optimized <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> weak-lensing mass clumps as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>, creating what we call the \u2018outskirt mass clumps\u2019 model. We find the optimized rms of this model to be 0.67\u2009arcsec. Comparing the overall model properties, we find that the external shear model is the least massive of the three. This arises from the fact that a pure external shear field has no intrinsic mass in our modelling scheme. The difference is small though, as shown by the two mass profiles in the right-hand panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> and the total mass contained within a radius <em>R</em> = 1.3 Mpc, which differs by only \u223c7\u2009per\u2009cent.</p>                        <a id=\"98964882\" scrollto-destination=\"98964882\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=kboIuE2vzP9X~Et-skd4AnS77wk6DcrrC9Qr9FTKVvsSv5bBTjNsUEMs~PswiTwBdXklEEI97CxLJXnARvk~-k~2tuI-Fe0rVGCfVnm0sZTVVpBlMMPXHrjW0toV4Inx2toxykruHTVa3EtmjqVhjUQ8uGjQUqTspS21pHFWFcoZyVP2sUATgByQLx0NaxZViXyJWiPOjwrijm3uRfFrAixywk0sy2nT9dIof41-b7~uvMKiF-bXXUSwtBZrYoS5CMxleL6PSyuVp46DaJP6LG8dztKV0yTfNhQbZ4rIO0AwU609R29zhpyeweGy9Zr~rX82HecERcsa1kfRREDpvw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: mass map of the model included mass clump in the outskirts following J16 nomenclature. The blue box is \u223c290\u2009kpc large and corresponds to the region where the shear comparison was made (Fig.\u200911). Circles show the outskirts mass potentials which correspond to the two scaling relations, red circles are associated with high luminosity counterparts, while orange circles group the other potentials (see Section\u00a05.2). Top right: differential mass profile of three models. \u2018Reference\u2019 is the model using only spectroscopic constraints and clumps in the WFC3 FoV, \u2018External shear\u2019 adds a constant external shear to the previous model and the \u2018Outskirts potentials\u2019 model replaces the constant shear with the mass clumps in the outskirts, which are represented by the circles in the left-hand panel. Lower right: integrated mass profiles of each of the previous models. The three points represent the mass at 1.3\u2009Mpc found by three weak-lensing studies. The mass profile is computed on a circular radius centred on the first BCG in the southern cluster core.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964882/stx1971fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964882\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=H97Xwy-jVztUWzfEf61-e2nBjQdUFcbb0CewRVP1kwZCIUMgcBhM6aZCo324kP6QKFK9bj4s41IR-06YRMNlIMuBFJfCYmgvvVdyDgfLvx6CyYFZY9wv0IjBXRrqtYmZNyHHmSqbDz8pz7nJpnUiGHbqXyrnt6efVCoKT4zhQnlo7XJrQkYvFqFxMBF64edjqLoPnrc5CeiC2MjMhpJwG-STuzfbnCQr2-tnq4EfnM8d0kfEj1YmwE0ZkZFZ2FeU2AklTbQ4VIEzAk7wLIiuy46f3f09Oaw-ytLwpxcKR8Y9Ob-Soz3rYESrZr0Jew9qXMd6wXF6fJxG6yX3wtPB1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964882&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: mass map of the model included mass clump in the outskirts following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> nomenclature. The blue box is \u223c290\u2009kpc large and corresponds to the region where the shear comparison was made (Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>). Circles show the outskirts mass potentials which correspond to the two scaling relations, red circles are associated with high luminosity counterparts, while orange circles group the other potentials (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a>). Top right: differential mass profile of three models. \u2018Reference\u2019 is the model using only spectroscopic constraints and clumps in the WFC3 FoV, \u2018External shear\u2019 adds a constant external shear to the previous model and the \u2018Outskirts potentials\u2019 model replaces the constant shear with the mass clumps in the outskirts, which are represented by the circles in the left-hand panel. Lower right: integrated mass profiles of each of the previous models. The three points represent the mass at 1.3\u2009Mpc found by three weak-lensing studies. The mass profile is computed on a circular radius centred on the first BCG in the southern cluster core.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=kboIuE2vzP9X~Et-skd4AnS77wk6DcrrC9Qr9FTKVvsSv5bBTjNsUEMs~PswiTwBdXklEEI97CxLJXnARvk~-k~2tuI-Fe0rVGCfVnm0sZTVVpBlMMPXHrjW0toV4Inx2toxykruHTVa3EtmjqVhjUQ8uGjQUqTspS21pHFWFcoZyVP2sUATgByQLx0NaxZViXyJWiPOjwrijm3uRfFrAixywk0sy2nT9dIof41-b7~uvMKiF-bXXUSwtBZrYoS5CMxleL6PSyuVp46DaJP6LG8dztKV0yTfNhQbZ4rIO0AwU609R29zhpyeweGy9Zr~rX82HecERcsa1kfRREDpvw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: mass map of the model included mass clump in the outskirts following J16 nomenclature. Circles show the outskirts mass potentials which correspond to the two scaling relations, red circles are associated with high luminosity counterparts, while orange circles group the other potentials (see Section\u00a05.2). The mass profile is computed on a circular radius centred on the first BCG in the southern cluster core.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964882/stx1971fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964882\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=H97Xwy-jVztUWzfEf61-e2nBjQdUFcbb0CewRVP1kwZCIUMgcBhM6aZCo324kP6QKFK9bj4s41IR-06YRMNlIMuBFJfCYmgvvVdyDgfLvx6CyYFZY9wv0IjBXRrqtYmZNyHHmSqbDz8pz7nJpnUiGHbqXyrnt6efVCoKT4zhQnlo7XJrQkYvFqFxMBF64edjqLoPnrc5CeiC2MjMhpJwG-STuzfbnCQr2-tnq4EfnM8d0kfEj1YmwE0ZkZFZ2FeU2AklTbQ4VIEzAk7wLIiuy46f3f09Oaw-ytLwpxcKR8Y9Ob-Soz3rYESrZr0Jew9qXMd6wXF6fJxG6yX3wtPB1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964882&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: mass map of the model included mass clump in the outskirts following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J16</a> nomenclature. The blue box is \u223c290\u2009kpc large and corresponds to the region where the shear comparison was made (Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>). Circles show the outskirts mass potentials which correspond to the two scaling relations, red circles are associated with high luminosity counterparts, while orange circles group the other potentials (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a>). Top right: differential mass profile of three models. \u2018Reference\u2019 is the model using only spectroscopic constraints and clumps in the WFC3 FoV, \u2018External shear\u2019 adds a constant external shear to the previous model and the \u2018Outskirts potentials\u2019 model replaces the constant shear with the mass clumps in the outskirts, which are represented by the circles in the left-hand panel. Lower right: integrated mass profiles of each of the previous models. The three points represent the mass at 1.3\u2009Mpc found by three weak-lensing studies. The mass profile is computed on a circular radius centred on the first BCG in the southern cluster core.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the main influence on the strong-lensing region by the outskirts mass clumps is a shear effect, we can compare the shear fields produced by this model and the pure external shear model. To do this, we generate a grid of shear values over the entire A2744 field, and measure the induced ellipticity in a region encompassing all of the strong-lensing constraints. The histograms in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> show the comparison between the external shear and the shear induced by the outskirts mass clumps. We see that the shear fields are entirely consistent in terms of strength \u03b3 and orientation \u03b8 for both models. For both parameters, the black line represent the mean value and the red area the 1\u03c3 error computed from all the models sampled during the external shear model optimization process. In both histograms, the blue distribution is computed from the outskirts mass model taking the shear value within the central region described before and shown in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. The good agreement between this distribution (initially detected based on weak-lensing effect at large radius) and the external shear parameters highlights the need for including environmental effects to better model the cluster core.</p>                        <a id=\"98964884\" scrollto-destination=\"98964884\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=E2kafEwkohXsyYOLgM6yTW8pmVbIBwQGIl5risavpiXQTN0ph-wcQpoK~s9GHXitukjqo3HftCv9g4PLXkatRO5p6GbqoGEbYFRyum-otJm30e7DTODpr9PenX3GxmDrIW856qOLDMKI6j5upz3r8vBBUC1~cox-4eprT1fogQiB0KnuePwaKzcYD3IUj~4GzIWixOrypyDeXTzuU0jtnob2-3~Psi0A1X3FvkfGL~4v3YhlyX5V7w8SuncJp-Esqhd7vTU1w8pwV2BF0qSPVc51R-zLLWinYyl4Xekb3dt74XvuhANJtH1N70CenpQMqxGSpRVsnbANBKBtCZVKIQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The left-hand panel shows the histogram of the \u03b3 value for the models included mass clumps in the outskirts, values are computed into a square region enclosing all the constraints and mark as a blue box in Fig.\u200910. The black line and the shaded red region represent the mean and its 1\u03c3 uncertainties for the value of the \u03b3 in the external shear model. The left-hand panel is similar and compare with the shear angle value \u03b8.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964884/stx1971fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964884\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=N98r8alug~n-iTYkwdjLLfvTh9ra5NejQP6I6WyLvu63iAN8hTVaWXOxdb51it3U9H7OqA7Q71aJlHQWdVmlxbXV52-O-NsjYUTR478M5QSDQQ9ScavFFtPpW4GUuntbsRMYy53FYqCFRkriSmwofZJ58EaQOz1jNaZQ8DujW-sbH7qANNnoQlJ6pfdwREfMoerPxNaZr8qwEYlhur0F-BRyx6Rt4PXqiIEhD-ZA5q5RLVgwH~9dLrf9wRGzx8O3DPTeIjwYzpAEqQf5RixnnmvDCygRFmSVVwE4GZcdyz3c6Ark0faExO9n~rTIdWreaHEmIavA03DKZPBIh3AhZA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964884&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The left-hand panel shows the histogram of the \u03b3 value for the models included mass clumps in the outskirts, values are computed into a square region enclosing all the constraints and mark as a blue box in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. The black line and the shaded red region represent the mean and its 1\u03c3 uncertainties for the value of the \u03b3 in the external shear model. The left-hand panel is similar and compare with the shear angle value \u03b8.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=E2kafEwkohXsyYOLgM6yTW8pmVbIBwQGIl5risavpiXQTN0ph-wcQpoK~s9GHXitukjqo3HftCv9g4PLXkatRO5p6GbqoGEbYFRyum-otJm30e7DTODpr9PenX3GxmDrIW856qOLDMKI6j5upz3r8vBBUC1~cox-4eprT1fogQiB0KnuePwaKzcYD3IUj~4GzIWixOrypyDeXTzuU0jtnob2-3~Psi0A1X3FvkfGL~4v3YhlyX5V7w8SuncJp-Esqhd7vTU1w8pwV2BF0qSPVc51R-zLLWinYyl4Xekb3dt74XvuhANJtH1N70CenpQMqxGSpRVsnbANBKBtCZVKIQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The left-hand panel shows the histogram of the \u03b3 value for the models included mass clumps in the outskirts, values are computed into a square region enclosing all the constraints and mark as a blue box in Fig.\u200910. The black line and the shaded red region represent the mean and its 1\u03c3 uncertainties for the value of the \u03b3 in the external shear model. The left-hand panel is similar and compare with the shear angle value \u03b8.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964884/stx1971fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964884\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=N98r8alug~n-iTYkwdjLLfvTh9ra5NejQP6I6WyLvu63iAN8hTVaWXOxdb51it3U9H7OqA7Q71aJlHQWdVmlxbXV52-O-NsjYUTR478M5QSDQQ9ScavFFtPpW4GUuntbsRMYy53FYqCFRkriSmwofZJ58EaQOz1jNaZQ8DujW-sbH7qANNnoQlJ6pfdwREfMoerPxNaZr8qwEYlhur0F-BRyx6Rt4PXqiIEhD-ZA5q5RLVgwH~9dLrf9wRGzx8O3DPTeIjwYzpAEqQf5RixnnmvDCygRFmSVVwE4GZcdyz3c6Ark0faExO9n~rTIdWreaHEmIavA03DKZPBIh3AhZA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964884&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The left-hand panel shows the histogram of the \u03b3 value for the models included mass clumps in the outskirts, values are computed into a square region enclosing all the constraints and mark as a blue box in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. The black line and the shaded red region represent the mean and its 1\u03c3 uncertainties for the value of the \u03b3 in the external shear model. The left-hand panel is similar and compare with the shear angle value \u03b8.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Moreover, we note that systems 15 and 16 (Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) are close enough to the N and NW clumps, that their positions are likely significantly affected by these masses. However, for simplicity \u2013 since both systems lack spectroscopic redshift \u2013 we did not use them as constraints in the outskirts mass model (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a>). It should be mentioned, though, that the masses shown in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> are large enough to produce multiple images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overall, thanks to numerous constraints with spectroscopy we are able to reach the level of sensitivity where mass clumps in the environment influence our model. The improvement in rms combined with the comparison between the external shear model and the outskirts mass model show that distant clumps (\u223c700\u2009kpc) contribute to the mass reconstruction in the vicinity of the cluster core by their induced shear. However, the mass profiles from both models tend to only separate one from each other at the end of the multiply imaged region (\u223c200\u2009kpc).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964887 id=\"98964887\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 The overall mass profile</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now compare the two best mass profiles found in this study (external shear and outskirt masses) to similar profiles derived from other post-HFF strong-lensing models of A2744. To do this, we construct the azimuthally averaged radial mass profile centred on the first BCG. The mass maps are generated by HFF modelling teams and are publicly available in the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST).<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> shows the mass profiles derived from all the studies, including our new analysis. The differential mass profile (middle panel) shows that within \u223c100\u2009kpc both of our mass profiles are lower than any other study (except the central 20\u2009kpc of the CATS (v3.1) model) and our 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties do not cover the difference in mass. The grey area represents the area where multiple images are expected, and corresponds to the region where our constraints are located. Between 100\u2009kpc and the end of the grey area different mass profiles tend to diverge one from another. Most of the models agree more with the outskirts mass model, which we will use as our fiducial model in the rest of the paper. Mass profiles are extrapolated beyond the edge of the grey area, since no hard strong-lensing constraints are found at these distances. Here, a clear separation between models appears: Bradac (v2), CATS (v3.1), Zitrin-NFW (v3) and our fiducial model profiles tend to keep a high density at large radii, while <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (v3), Sharon (v3) and our external-shear model generate a lower mass profile. At very large distances, the profile from Williams (v3) drops considerably lower than all others. These effects are seen in both panels of Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98964890\" scrollto-destination=\"98964890\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=S5WGjF6byERLxzYq8lktWPWPL5i~UnDv1t1pkbzpWDl~B7siYfHkgOaXCehlFyoocK0vzSDcvY~FRIuwTryhWO1JIEAZWXK9HHVjtsrYN0Su6DkZeQEdmhaf1MS9VedZBvAodVqX5vMichpTv8mWidnelPemvVIHn6Chjq93JBPyLDBPiYy53wKsrGOARQHBjBgKERJoloGXXWLji2p3y3LDi~Gng2FsRc2D9252p36AekguErmMg68Pyxb58D6VrxGSargjaBgXr8lSJO~q1540R~SXhgP2bkSHzBlGd1BX8AGQuPvNaLLAuThZCCYwbnFVPD6JQadyUr1NMw5q-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The integrated (upper panel), differential (middle panel) and ratio (lower panel) mass profiles of the cluster from different studies. The ratio is computed over our fiducial model, the one with clumps in the outskirts and only gold sample. The black line surrounded by the blue-shaded region represents the mass profile for the external shear and 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The black line surrounded by the shaded orange region represents mass profile for the fiducial model and the 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The grey area represents the region where multiple images used as constraints are located.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964890/stx1971fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964890\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=vuCXROb8TCMZHfg08tTPrHB4njYPuCKC~A82BuqasSj7mqnb~q71EUVYpu6iuS1LySoTnPRivqMK2N3wizhXBpD2UFDM8W77lmC1uooIu0J-L6U7Vobt-8~qAdpw2DfKCuDfsbfVCO0jJKRR2VR2d0STPltQsWkHXLedqDu-n6RX-K0ZwzbV-84wMPlJ7ttodNXh0K7Bz3JV5GH9yzrNh~INgQwprQs1fCBQUhrUlNbnvM8Fcln~rNII9~yUBXRIn9LZTi~cJS73MI8bB~v6FIZ0my8aOyXnFmSoPmrHRE5VUD2bjodDXNTFdyV04UmrLh24wyhxLy~EHAdHgcFZdg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964890&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The integrated (upper panel), differential (middle panel) and ratio (lower panel) mass profiles of the cluster from different studies. The ratio is computed over our fiducial model, the one with clumps in the outskirts and only <em>gold</em> sample. The black line surrounded by the blue-shaded region represents the mass profile for the external shear and 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The black line surrounded by the shaded orange region represents mass profile for the fiducial model and the 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The grey area represents the region where multiple images used as constraints are located.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=S5WGjF6byERLxzYq8lktWPWPL5i~UnDv1t1pkbzpWDl~B7siYfHkgOaXCehlFyoocK0vzSDcvY~FRIuwTryhWO1JIEAZWXK9HHVjtsrYN0Su6DkZeQEdmhaf1MS9VedZBvAodVqX5vMichpTv8mWidnelPemvVIHn6Chjq93JBPyLDBPiYy53wKsrGOARQHBjBgKERJoloGXXWLji2p3y3LDi~Gng2FsRc2D9252p36AekguErmMg68Pyxb58D6VrxGSargjaBgXr8lSJO~q1540R~SXhgP2bkSHzBlGd1BX8AGQuPvNaLLAuThZCCYwbnFVPD6JQadyUr1NMw5q-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The integrated (upper panel), differential (middle panel) and ratio (lower panel) mass profiles of the cluster from different studies. The ratio is computed over our fiducial model, the one with clumps in the outskirts and only gold sample. The black line surrounded by the blue-shaded region represents the mass profile for the external shear and 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The black line surrounded by the shaded orange region represents mass profile for the fiducial model and the 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The grey area represents the region where multiple images used as constraints are located.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964890/stx1971fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964890\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=vuCXROb8TCMZHfg08tTPrHB4njYPuCKC~A82BuqasSj7mqnb~q71EUVYpu6iuS1LySoTnPRivqMK2N3wizhXBpD2UFDM8W77lmC1uooIu0J-L6U7Vobt-8~qAdpw2DfKCuDfsbfVCO0jJKRR2VR2d0STPltQsWkHXLedqDu-n6RX-K0ZwzbV-84wMPlJ7ttodNXh0K7Bz3JV5GH9yzrNh~INgQwprQs1fCBQUhrUlNbnvM8Fcln~rNII9~yUBXRIn9LZTi~cJS73MI8bB~v6FIZ0my8aOyXnFmSoPmrHRE5VUD2bjodDXNTFdyV04UmrLh24wyhxLy~EHAdHgcFZdg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964890&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The integrated (upper panel), differential (middle panel) and ratio (lower panel) mass profiles of the cluster from different studies. The ratio is computed over our fiducial model, the one with clumps in the outskirts and only <em>gold</em> sample. The black line surrounded by the blue-shaded region represents the mass profile for the external shear and 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The black line surrounded by the shaded orange region represents mass profile for the fiducial model and the 3\u03c3 statistical uncertainties. The grey area represents the region where multiple images used as constraints are located.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The discrepancies in the inner core could be due to the new hard constraints we add to our mass models, while the discrepancies outside the multi-imaged region may be related to different aspects of the modelling technique and their sensitivity to environmental effects. By probing the overall discrepancies in the mass profiles between different analyses, we can begin to understand the magnitude of systematic uncertainties and their overall effects on the modelling.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to other parametric models (v3 from CATS, <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> and Sharon), our fiducial model reaches a similar, or slightly higher rms (0.6\u2009arcsec). The main difference is a higher ratio between the number of constraints (<em>k</em>) and the number of free parameters (<em>n</em>), which can be used as a metric on the level of constraints available. Thanks to the large number of spectroscopic redshifts available for the <em>gold</em> systems, we obtain <em>k</em>/<em>n</em>\u00a0=\u00a0134/30\u00a0=\u00a04.5 compared to 70/30\u00a0=\u00a02.33 for CATS (v3), and 146/100\u00a0=\u00a01.46 for <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (v3) (Kawamata et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The ratio between constraints and free parameters in our model is comparable to the Sharon (v3) model (<em>k</em>/<em>n</em>\u00a0=\u00a0108/27\u00a0=\u00a04, Sharon private communication), but they use multiple emission knots in each galaxy as constraints, making them not strictly independent. We note that our current model is able to accommodate a large number of constraints with only a small number of free parameters, which means that we are reaching a limit (in rms) with this method.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98964893 id=\"98964893\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-4>6.4 Estimating the level of systematics in mass models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our fiducial model, containing mass clumps in the outskirts, constrained with the <em>gold</em> set of multiple images and released as CATS (v4) as part of the FFs model challenge, shows a <em>statistical</em> error of \u03c3<sub>stat</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u2009per\u2009cent on the mass density profile in the cluster core (see Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> and Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.3</a>). This error is comparable to the estimates from the previous CATS (v3) model. However, these uncertainties only arise from the statistical fluctuation of models during the minimization procedure and do not reflect inherent <em>systematic</em> uncertainties. Such uncertainties can arise from the choice of constraints, the model parametrization and scatter on the position of multiples images due to unaccounted structures within the cluster or over the LOS.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thanks to our large sample of spectrosopic redshifts, we are able to significantly improve our model compared to previous work. This is mainly thanks to our ability to unambiguously identify multiply imaged systems used as model constraints, reducing the overall systematic uncertainty on the model. Specifically, we no longer misidentify the configuration of systems, which has been problematic in the past. A key example of this can be seen in the reconfiguration of previously identified systems 5 and 47, where we subdivide these objects into two distinct segments. As highlighted in Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> and in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, models with the wrong configuration do not converge towards a good model, instead straying far from the true spectroscopic redshift and maintaining a high final rms (1.87\u2009arcsec). In addition to the mass profile, misidentification can also affect magnification predictions and lead to a biased measurement on the properties of lensed galaxies. However, such topics are outside of the scope of this paper. Johnson &amp; Sharon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) studied systematic uncertainties on the lensing mass reconstruction for the simulated lensing cluster ARES (Meneghetti et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). ARES, and its companion HERA, are simulated lensing clusters designed by the HFF project as a way to fairly compare mass models from different teams. From their work on ARES, Johnson &amp; Sharon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) investigate the effect of systematic uncertainties arising from the choice of lensing constraints, dividing all constraints in two categories: spectroscopic and non-spectroscopic. By testing a series of combinations of constraints with and without spectroscopy, they conclude that 25 spectroscopic systems (among the 66 available in the ARES cluster) are required to get the true rms of the cluster and reach the systematic level of uncertainty. In their work, they also discover that constraints distributed inhomogeneously (either spatially or in redshift) lead to strongly disfavoured models. We believe that with our 29 systems evenly distributed around the cluster, our level of uncertainty drops very close to the systematic limit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As the systematics likely arise from different contributions, we try to estimate their level using complementary techniques. First, we try to highlight the reduced level of systematic error brought about by the addition of new spectroscopic redshifts. To do this, we modify our fiducial model, keeping only systems identified by Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) as objects with fixed redshifts (though we update all redshifts to their current MUSE values.) We leave the redshifts of the other systems as free parameters, which are then optimized during minimization. To characterize the systematic differences, we compare the final model-optimized redshifts to the spectroscopic values used in the fiducial model. This comparison is shown in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>. From the figure, we see that the optimized redshifts are systematically higher than the values measured from spectroscopy. This impacts the overall mass distribution of the cluster and can affect our interpretation of the final results.</p>                        <a id=\"98964897\" scrollto-destination=\"98964897\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=XNki~lx6WpycivC~vMmYqPXzrcpC6kxTmPcCK4bNIX5vnosLhfAlfBDhNdQoZ3LeKoj2Zwpf7Iv3xI7tw6T~2Id74wLxn7cS2q~tHhRChQdUpyQ48sXREtxHR9AB1HUPeiPK38cJSL1gpf-Mt5pN6RZ9oaWVYYFrIOqArjk6gDnHQN2EVa8aHhhJpiie~2VqsKq5i~bDHSSmMU8AU957wXk2wtZo54KDWEX2TKKoJkU98O1BcVGIG-2dOPVFaLDFCEd~hXMVP9UWSuopyMbcMwYdORl-YJA9LhAohvQRQCZpq28IfqsI4bmsjCUZFn53aPtwMVrhy74brvxGxec5fA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between model-predicted redshifts and the new spectroscopic measurements. The models used for prediction is based on the fiducial model (mass clumps in the outskirts plus gold sample), but newly measured redshifts compared to Wang et\u00a0al. (2015) are optimized during the minimization procedure. The colour codes for the minimal distance between two images from the same systems whereas symbols show how many images compose the systems.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98964897/stx1971fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98964897\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/stx1971fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&Signature=tlBwdvvHWdKniKR1NePzYpmU9H4eLiryzga2xS6WjTYA1eP3j8jDO-LfkAuzfvNl2tM-PwZ9UfUSMuHM089dOpn4qeWWYyv0Kxyi2xcXz4QmErImYSj~kYURXcZltG0bGsUBzduEAFNfY3OOFyhbGdV3IRyk7fec2eU0BGCrN57GUbcgrlRN3gKMa3juLEZHbJjReCd7ph7jLJS-cNTDO6CJOGOiJ-7rPBcdG5MX9GUU6dCtBUwHB4GRhhDPRRMtUAgf0qLJRZacfaO1fXXsm02zmZTsOd2LIIjxKDwF9AEkOhmd0sUWHBiPbRr1s~rkWCUIW~7K-aH99f4uecPY3Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98964897&ar=4060735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1971fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between model-predicted redshifts and the new spectroscopic measurements. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) are optimized during the minimization procedure. The colour codes for the minimal distance between two images from the same systems whereas symbols show how many images compose the systems.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/473/1/10.1093_mnras_stx1971/1/m_stx1971fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263272&amp;Signature=XNki~lx6WpycivC~vMmYqPXzrcpC6kxTmPcCK4bNIX5vnosLhfAlfBDhNdQoZ3LeKoj2Zwpf7Iv3xI7tw6T~2Id74wLxn7cS2q~tHhRChQdUpyQ48sXREtxHR9AB1HUPeiPK38cJSL1gpf-Mt5pN6RZ9oaWVYYFrIOqArjk6gDnHQN2EVa8aHhhJpiie~2VqsKq5i~bDHSSmMU8AU957wXk2wtZo54KDWEX2TKKoJkU98O1BcVGIG-2dOPVFaLDFCEd~hXMVP9UWSuopyMbcMwYdORl-YJA9LhAohvQRQCZpq28IfqsI4bmsjCUZFn53aPtwMVrhy74brvxGxec5fA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between model-predicted redshifts and the new spectroscopic measurements.
